editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE City-Night-Cap: OR, Crede quod habes, & habes. A Tragi-Comedy.
As it was Acted with great Applauſe, by Her Majeſties Servants, at the Phoenix in Drury Lane.
LONDON: Printed by Ja: Cottrel, for Samuel Speed, at the Signe of the Printing-Preſs in St. Paul's Church-yard. 1661.

list.item: Duke of Venice, Brother to Abſtemia.

list.head: Women ACTORS.
list.item: Abſtemia, Lorenzo's Wife, and Siſter to the Duke Venice.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: THou ſha't try her yet once more.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt do't:
If thou be'ſt my friend, thou'lt do't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Try your fair wife?
You know 'cis an old point, and wonderous frequent
In moſt of our Italian Comedies.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What do I eare for that? let him ſeek new ones
Cannot make old ones better; and this new point
(Young Sir) may produce new ſmooth paſſages,
Tranſcending thoſe precedent: pray will ye do't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray fool your ſelf no farther; twice you have ſwaid me,
Twice I have try'd her; and 'tis not yet, ye know,
Ten days ſince our reconciliation:
How will it ſhew in you ſo near a Kinſman
To the Duke, nay, having woven your ſelf into
The cloſe-wrought Myſtery of Opinion,
Where you remain a ſouldier, a man
Of brain and quality, to put your friend
Again on ſuch a buſineſs, and to expoſe
Your fair wife to the tempeſt of temptation?
And by the white unſpotted Cheek of Truth,
She is—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A woman.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A good woman.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Piſh.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: As far from your Diſtruſt, as bad ones are from Truth:
She is in love with Vertue, would not boaſt it,
But that her whole Life is a well-writ ſtory,
Where each word ſtands ſo well plac'd, that it paſſes
Inquiſitive Detraction, to correct
She's modeſt, but not fullen; and loves ſilence,
Not that ſhe wants apt words, (for when ſhe ſpeaks,
She enflames Love with wonder) but becauſe
She calls wiſe ſilence the ſouls harmony.
She's truly chaſte, yet ſuch a foe to coyneſs,
The pooreſt call her courteous; and which is excellent,
(Though fair and young) ſhe ſhuns to expoſe her ſelf
To the opinion of ſtrange eyes: ſhe either ſeldom
Or never walks abroad but in your company,
And then with ſuch ſweet haſhfulneſs, as if
She were venturing on crack'd ice; and takes delight
To ſtep into the print your foot hath made,
And will follow you whole fields: ſo ſhe will drive
Tediouſneſs out of Time, with her ſweet Character:
And therefore, good my friend, forbear to try
The Gold has paſt the fire.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Thou fooliſh friend,
Beauty, like the Herb Larix, is cool i'th' water,
But hot i'th' ſtomack: women are ſmooth flatterers, but cunning injurers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou wonderous yellow friend,
Temper an Antidote with Antimony;
And 'tis infectious: mix Jealouſie with Marriage,
It poyſons Vertue: let the child feel the ſting,
He'll fly the Honey-comb: Has ſhe one action
That can expoſe you to diſtruſt?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Oh! when the Fleſander leaf looks moſt green,
The fap is then moſt bitter: an approv'd appearance
Is no authentick inſtance; ſhe that is lip-holy,
Is many times heart-hollow.—Here ſhe comes.
A Prayer-book in her hand! Oh hypocriſie!
How fell'ſt thou firſt in love with woman? wilt try again
But this one time?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Condition'd you will ſtand
Ear-witneſs to our conference, that you may take
In at your ear, a Vertue that will teach
Your erring ſoul to wonder.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: He would wittal me,
With a conſent to my own Horns: I will;
I'll give thee a new occaſion: There lurks in womans blood
A vindicating ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: I came, Sir, to give you notice,
Count Lodovico, Stroimo, Spinoſo, and Pandulpho, with the reſt
Of the Conſilliadory, certifie,
They are ſetting forth to meet the Duke your Kinſman
Returning from Venice.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Oh, there he has ſeen the Duke your Brother.

sp.speaker: Abst.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, and they ſtay but for your company.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And you're cloy'd with't—Kicks her and Exit. She weeps.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And will you ſtill be uſed thus? Oh Madam,
I do confeſs, twice I have batter'd at
The Fort I fain would vanquiſh, and I know
Ye hold out more 'cauſe ye would ſeem a Souldier,
Then in hate to the Affailant; I am again
Inflam'd with thoſe ſweet fountains from whence flow
Such a pair of ſtreams: Oh ſtrong force of deſire!
The quality ſhould quench, hath ſet on fire:
I love you in your ſorrows.

sp.speaker: Abst.
sp.l: And I ſorrow in nothing but your love; twice, Philippo,
Have I not beat back the impetuous ſtorm
Of thy inceſſant rudeneſs? wilt thou again
Darken fair Honour with Diſhoneſty?
Thou know'ſt my Lord hath long and truly lov'd thee
In the wiſdom of a Friend, in a fair Cauſe;
He wears his good ſword for thee, lays his heart
A lodger in thy boſome, proclaims thee Partner
In all he hath, but me; Oh be not counterfeit:
We all conclude, a Diamond with Clouds
The Goldſmith caſts into his duſt; and a Gentleman
So blemiſh'd in his Honour, blots his Name
Out of the Heralds Book, ſtands a loſt man
In Goodneſs and Opinion: Oh Philippo,
Make me once more ſo happy to believe
'Tis but a pointed paſſion.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Moſt acute Witch!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come, learn of your City-Wagtail; with one eye
Violently love your Husband, and with t'other
Wink at your Friend.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I will not truſt you, Brother.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He ſeeks, will ye not have him finde? cries ye out,
In his mad fits, a Strumpet, rails at all women,
Upon no cauſe, but becauſe you are one:
He gives wound upon wound, and then pours Vinegar
Into your bleeding Reputation,
Poyſon'd with bitter Calumny: Pox on him;
Pile a reciprocal reward upon him;
Let Ballet-mongers crown him with their ſcorns:
VVho buys the Bucks Head, well deſerves the Horns:
Demur not on't, but clap them on.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: You are, Sir, juſt like the Indian Hyſop, prais'd of ſtrangers,
For the ſweet ſcent; but hated of the inhabitants,
For the injurious quality: Can he love the VVife,
That would betray the Husband? Haſt thou not ſeen me
Bear all his injuries, as the Ocean ſuffers
The angry Bark to plough thorow her Boſome,
And yet is preſently ſo ſmooth, the eye
Cannot perceive where the wide wound was made:
And cannot this inform, I love him better
In his ſow'r Follies, then you, in your ſweet Flatteries?
If Verona hath obſerved any Errours in me,
I well may call for grace to amend them;
But will never fall from grace to befriend you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: VVith what a Majeſty good women thunder!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: 'Has given her ſome cloſe nod that I am here.

sp.speaker: Abst.
sp.l: Rip up the end of thy intent, and ſee
How ſhame and fear do lurk where you would walk,
Like a pair of Serpents in a flow'ry Mead:
Luſt ſees with pleaſure, but with fear doth cread.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Very brave woman!

sp.speaker: Abst.
sp.l: VVhat is the pleaſure thou purſu'ſt? a ſin
Finiſh'd with infinite ſorrows: read and find
How barb'rous Nations puniſh it with death:
How a minutes ſin ſo ſtolen, though in the Face
Sit ſummer calms, all ſmooth, yet thou wilt hear,
From the Eternal Alarm of thy Conſcience,
How it ſets within thy ſoul continual tempeſts,
Thunder and diſmal blackneſs: mark but the courſe
Of the holy-ſeeming hollow-man, and ſee
How he that glories Heaven with no Honour,
Covets to glorifie himſelf with Honeſty.
And to put you paſt your hopes, let me leave this with you;
Thou mayſt hold an Elephant with a thread, eat fire
And not be burnt, or catch Birds with deſire;
Quench Flame with Oyl, cut Diamonds with Glaſs,
Pierce Steel with Feathers; this thou mayſt bring to paſs,
Sooner then hope to ſteal that Husband's Right,
Whoſe Wife ſeems honeſt, and no Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What think you now, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why now I do think it poſſible for the world
To have an honeſt woman in't.—Good-buy, Sir;
I muſt go meet the Duke: adieu. Phil. Farewel:
Oh Jealouſie! how near thou dwell'ſt to Hell!
sp.stage: Enter Lodovico, Pandulpho, Spinoſo, Jaſpro, and Iovani, and Clown.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The Duke not ſeven leagues off! my horſe, Rogues.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Our negligence deſerves juſt blame; and how
'T will pleaſe his Grace to conſter it, we know not.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: But where's your fair chaſte wife, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Marry, with my man Franciſco; Oh that fellow!
She were undone without him: for indeed
She takes great pleaſure in him; he learns her Muſick:
To hear what counſel ſhe will give him! if he but ſcrew
His look ſometimes, with the pin, ſhe will tell him ſtraight,
'T was an unchriſtian look: I love him dearly,

sp.speaker: Spin.
sp.l: But can your Honour never woo your Lady
To a more ſociable affability?
She will not kiſs, nor drink, nor talk, but againſt new faſhions.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Oh, Sir, ſhe is my Crown; nor is it requiſite
sp.p: VVomen ſhould be ſo ſociable; I have had ſuch a coil with her, to bring her but to look out at window; when we were firſt married, ſhe would not drink a cup of wine, unleſs nine parts of it were water.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Admired Temperance!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay, and ye knew all, my Lords, ye would ſay ſo: t'other day I brought an Engliſh Gentleman home with me, to try a Horſe I ſhould ſell him; he (as ye know their cuſtom, though it be none of ours) makes at her lips the firſt daſh.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: He daſh'd her out of countenance, I'm ſure of that.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: She did ſo powt and ſpit, that my hot-brain'd Gallant could not forbear, but ask the cauſe: quoth ſhe—

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: No, Sir, ſhe ſpit again, before quoth ſhe left her lips.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I think ſhe did indeed; but then quoth ſhe, A kiſs, Sir, is ſins earneſt-penny: is't not true, Pambo?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Very true, Sir; by the ſame token, Quoth he to her again, If you diſlike the penny, Lady, pray let me change it into Engliſh half-pence; and ſo gave her two for't.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: But how ſhe vex't then! then ſhe rattled him, and told him roundly, Though confidence made Cuckolds in England, ſhe could no Coxcombs in Italy.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: But did ye mark how bitterly he clos'd it with a midling Jeſt?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What was that, I prethee?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Why quoth he to her again, Confidence makes not ſo many Cuckolds in England, but Craft picks open more Padlocks in Italy.

sp.speaker: Jov.
sp.p: That was ſomething ſharp—But here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Ye ſhall ſee how I'll put ye all upon her preſently.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Then I ſhall take my turn.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Have you chang'd the Ditty you laſt ſet?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I have, Madam.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The Conceit may ſtand, but I hope you have cloath'd the method in a more Chriſtian-like apparel.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I have, Lady.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pray let me hear it now.

l.hi: She that in theſe days looks for Truth,
Seldom or never findes, in ſooth.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That's wondrous well.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Yes in ſadneſs.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Peace, ſirrah; nay, ſhe's built of modeſty.

l.hi: Even as a wicked Kiſs defiles the Lips,
So do new faſhions her that through them trips.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Very modeſt language.

l.hi: She that doth pleaſure uſe for what 'twill bring her,
will pluck a Roſe, although ſhe prick her finger.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Put in hurt her finger, good Francis; the phraſe will be more decent.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Y'are a wondrous happy man in one ſo vertuous.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, ye ſhall have no Count Lorenzo of me, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Nor no Count Lorenzo's Lady of your wife, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sweet Chick, I come to take leave of thee: finger in nye already!
VVe are all to meet the Duke this afternoon, Bird,
VVho is now come from Venice: thou mayſt walk and ſee
The Count Lorenzo's Lady.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Lae, ſhe's too merry for my company.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Too merry! I have ſeen her ſad,
But very ſeldom merry.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I mean, my Lord,
That ſhe can walk, tell Tales, run in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: VVhy then your Ladiſhip may hold your tongue, ſay nothing, and walk in the Orchard.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: She can drink a cup of wine not delay'd with water.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: VVhy then you may drink a cup of water without wine.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay, if a Noble man come to ſee her Lord,
She will let him kiſs her too, againſt our cuſtom.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: VVhy a modeſt woman may be kiſt by accident,
Yet not give the leaſt touch to her Reputation.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: VVell ſaid, touch her home.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay, but they may not: ſhe that will kiſs, they ſay,
VVill do worſe, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Jov.
sp.l: VVhy I have ſeen you, Madam, kiſt againſt your will.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Againſt my will it may be I have been kiſt indeed.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Pſhew, there's nothing againſt a womans will; and I dare be ſworn, if my Lady kiſs but any one man, 'tis becauſe ſhe cannot do with all.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, I know that to be true, my Lords, and at this time,
Becauſe ye cannot do with all, pray kiſs them in order;
Kiſs her all over, gentlemen, and we are gone.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay good my Lord, 'tis againſt our Nations cuſtome.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I care not; let naturals love Nations:
My humour's my humour.

sp.speaker: Spin.
sp.l: I muſt have my turn too then.

sp.speaker: Jov.
sp.l: It muſt go round.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Look how ſhe ſpits now.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: The deeper the ſweeter, Lady

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: The neerer the bone, the ſweeter the fleſh, Lady.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How now, ſauce-box!

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Did not my Lord bid the gentlemen kiſs you all over?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I have ſweet cauſe to be jealous, have I not, gentlemen? no; Crede quod habes, & habes ſtill; he that believes he has horns, has them. Will you go bring my horſe, ſir?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I will bring your horſe, ſir; and your horſe ſhall bring his tail with him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Francis, I prithee ſtay thou at home with thy Lady: get thy inſtrument ready; this melancholy will ſpoil her: before theſe Lords here, make her but laugh, when we are gone.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Laugh before theſe Lords when they are gone, ſir!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Piſh, I mean, make her laugh heartily before we come home; and before theſe Lords, I promiſe thee a leaſe of forty Crowns per annum.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Can ye tell whether ſhe be tickliſh, ſir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Oh, infinitely tickliſh!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I'll deſerve your leaſe, then, ere you come home, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And thou ſhalt ha't y faith boy.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Your horſe is ready, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: My Lords, I think we have ſtaid with the longeſt; farewel Doll: Crede quod habes, & habes, gallants.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Our horſes ſhall fetch it up again: farewel ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.p: Adieu ſweet Miſtres: and whenſoere I marry, fortune turn up to me no worſe Card then you are.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: And whenſoere I marry, Venus ſend me a Card may ſave fortune the labour, and turn up her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How now? why loyter you behind? why ride not you along with your Lord?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: To lie with your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: In the bed, upon the bed, or under the bed.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why, how now Francis?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This is the plain truth on't, I would lie with ye.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I know too that you will lie with me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay but Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Plague of Francis: I am neither Frank nor Francis,
But a Gentleman of Millain, that even there
Heard of your Beauty, which Report there guarded
With ſuch a Chaſtity, the glittering'ſt ſin
Held no Artillery of power to ſhake it.
Upon which, I reſolv'd to try concluſions;
Aſſum'd this name and fortune, ſought this ſervice:
And I will tell ye truly what I gueſs you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You will not raviſh me, Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No; but unravel ye, in two lines Experiences writ lately:

l.hi: Extreams in Vertue, are but Clouds to Vice:
She'll do i'th' Dark, who is i'th' Day too nice.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Indeed ye do not well to bely me thus.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come, I'll lie with thee, Wench, and make all well again; though your confident Lord makes uſe of Crede quod habes & habes, and holds it impoſſible for any to be a Cuckold, can believe himſelf none: I would have his Lady have more wit, and clap them on.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And truly Francis, ſome women now would do't.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Who can you chuſe more convenient to practiſe with, then me, whom he doats on? where ſhall a man finde a friend but at home? ſo you break one Proverbs pate, and give the other a plainer: is't a match, wench?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: VVell, for once it is: But and ye do any more, indeed I'll tell my Husband.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But when ſhall this once be? now?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Now? no indeed, Francis.
It ſhall be ſoon at night, when your Lord's come home.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then! how is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Poſſible? women can make any of theſe things poſſible,

sp.speaker: Francis:
sp.p: now many caſualties may croſs us; but ſoon at night my Lord, I'm ſure, will be ſo ſleepy, what with his journey, and deep healths for the Dukes return, that before he goes to Bed (as he uſes ſtill, when he has been hard a drinking) he will ſleep upon the bed in's cloaths ſo ſound, Bells would not wake him, rung in the chamber.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The Cuckold ſlumbers: though his VVife hit him o'th'
Forehead with her Heel, he dreams of no ſuch matter.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Now Pambo, that makes him merry in his Chamber, ſhall, when the candle's our, and he aſleep, bring you into the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But will he be ſecret?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: VVill he good ſoul! I am not to try him now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Sfoot this is brave,
My kind Lords fool, is my cunning Ladies knave:
But pray how then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: VVhen you are in at door on right before you, you ſhall feel the bed; give me but ſoftly a touch, I'll riſe, and follow you into the next chamber: but truly and you do not uſe me kindly, I ſhall cry out and ſpoil all.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Uſe you kindly! was Lady ere us'd cruelly i'th' dark? do you but prepare Pambo and your maid, let me alone with her Miſtres: about 11 I deſire to be expected

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And till the clock ſtrick 12, I'll lie awake.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Now ye dare kiſs.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Once with my friend, or ſo: yet you may take two, Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My caſt is Ams-Ace then.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Deuce-Ace had got the game.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: VVhy then you're welcome. Adieu my daintie Miſtres.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Farwel kind Francis

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I have given them all the ſlip, the Duke and all;
And am at home before them: I cannot reſt,
Philippo and my wife run in my mind ſo:
I know no cauſe why I ſhould truſt him more
Then all the world beſide: I remember
He told her that I bought the Bucks Head, therefore
Deſerv'd the horns: although I bid him try her,
Yet I did not bid him bid her with one eye
Love me, and with the other wink at a friend.
How we long to grow familiar with affliction!
And as many words do aptly hold concordance
To make one ſentence, juſt ſo many cauſes
Seem to agree, when conceit makes us Cuckolds.
And here comes proof apparent, hand in hand too;
Now their palms meet, that graſpe begers a Baſtard.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By your white hand I ſwear 'twas only ſo.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Poyſon of Toads betwixt ye.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Philippo, you have fully ſatisfied me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Inſatiate whore! could not I ſatisfie ye?
I ſhall commit a murder, if I ſtay:
I'll go forge Thunder for ye. Oh let me
Never more marry! what plague can tranſcend
A whoriſh wife, and a perfidious friend!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By the unblemiſh'd faith, then, of a gentleman;
And by your potent goodneſs, a great oath;
(For you are greatly good) by truth it ſelf,
(For ſtill I ſwear by you) what again hath paſt,
Was at the firſt, but tryal of her chaſtity
Far above time or ſtorie: as I ſpeak truth,
So may I proſper.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: And came theſe tryals from your breſt only?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Only from my breſt; and by the ſweet
Excellent bluſh of vertue, there is in you
Plenty of truth and goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: You have nobly
Appeas'd the ſtorm o'ertook you; and you are
Again a good man.
sp.stage: Enter Lorenzo, Pandulpho, Spinoſo, Jaſpro, Jovani.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Trayto to truth and friendſhip!
Did not mine honour hold me, I ſhould rip out
That bluſhing hypocrite, thy heart, that hath broke
So ſtrong a tie of faith; but behold,
How much of man is in me! there I caſt them
From this believing heart, to the iron hand
Of law, the wrong'd mans ſaint.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: My Lord, here's warrant for what's done immediate from
The Duke, by force of which you're early i'th' morning
Before his Grace, to anſwer to ſuch injuries
The Count Lorenzo ſhall alledge againſt you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Injuries! Why friend, what injuries?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Can ye ſpell Stag, ſir? 'tis four letters with two horns.
Good gentlemen convey him from my furie,
For fear of greater miſchief.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou yellow fool.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: I would you would inſtruct me, noble ſir,
But how to underſtand all this.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Do ye ſee her? look on her all, and wonder: did ye ever
ſee ſo foul guilt ſtand underneath a look ſo innocent?

sp.speaker: Jov.
sp.l: I ſhould have pawn'd my blood upon her honour.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Colours not in grain,
Make as fair ſhew, but are more apt to ſtain.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Ye Whore.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Look to the Lady

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Look to her! hang her: let me ſend her now
To th' devil, with all her ſins upon her head.

sp.speaker: Spin.
sp.l: Bear her in gently, and ſee her guarded.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You are too violent, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That men ſhould ever marry! that we ſhould lay our heads, and take our hornes up out of womans laps.

sp.speaker: Jov.
sp.l: Be patient, good ſir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Yes, and go make porguns.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: 'Tis late, and ſleep would do you good, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Sleep! why do you think I am mad, ſir?

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Not I, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Then you do lye, my Lord,
For I am mad, horn-mad: I ſhall be acted
In our Theaters of Verona. Oh what poyſon's
Like a falſe friend? and what plague more ruinous
Then a laſcivious wife? they ſteal our joyes,
And fill us with afflictions; they leave our names
Hedg'd in with calumny: in their falſe hearts
Crocodiles breed, who make grief their diſguiſe,
And in betraying teares, ſtill through their eyes.
Oh! he that can believe he ſleeps ſecure
In a falſe friends oaths, or in a bad wives arms,
Truſts Circes witchcraft, and Calipſoes charms.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: 'Tis late, let's to the Court.

div.head: Actus Secundus.
div.stage: A bed thruſt out: Lodovico ſleeping in his cloaths: Dorathea in bed: Enter Clown leading in Franciſco.

sp.speaker: Fran
sp.l: SOftly ſweet Pambo: are we in the Chamber yet?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Within a yard of my Lady, and ye can be quiet.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Art ſure my Lord's aſleep?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: I know not, I'll go and ask him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, no, no, do not wake him; we are undone then man.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, now do I ſee, cuckold-making is as tickliſh a profeſſion as Cunny-catching: my Lord was ſo paid with healths at court, he's faſt enough.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But ſtill I purſue wonder, why my Lady ſhould preſcribe this ſtrange, nay wonderous deſperate way to her deſires.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Is that a queſtion to ask now? would you would groap out the bed; for I ſleep in my talk, I am ſure of that.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: VVe are loſt for ever: did he not cough?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing but the laſt cup comes up in ſtew'dbroath: if ever you make true whore maſter, I'll be bound to reſign my place up to my Lords page: Sea-ſick before you come to th' ſalt-water? let me go in your ſtead.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, I'll venter, ſtood a gulph between belching up
A Tempeſt. Oh valiant luſt!
How reſolute thou go'ſt to acts unjuſt!
Pambo, good night.
Deſire drowns fear, in preſuppos'd delight:

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Turn of your left hand, 'twill lead you to the devil, to my Lady, I ſhould ſay, preſently.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let me four ſteps on the left hand: I have the bed, and on this ſide ſhe lies: 'Sfoot there's a beard? but all's well yet, ſhe lies on this ſide ſure:
sp.l: I have her, 'tis her hand, I know the touch:
It melts me into paſſion; I have much ado
To contain my wild deſires: as the wind ſtrains
In Caverns lock'd; ſo through my big-ſwolne veynes,
My blood cuts capers.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Fortunate Francis, that was wrap'd in's mothers ſmock.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Give me your hand Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: There 'tis: I melt already.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My Lord, Count Lodovico, awake.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I am loſt for ever, Madam,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: If I pull too hard, I ſhall pull her out o'th' bed too.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My Lord, will ye not wake?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What's the matter? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How I do dwindle!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pray hear me ſir, I cannot ſleep till you
Have reſolv'd me one thing.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: VVhat is't, ſweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Of all your men, which do you love beſt?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: That's a ſtrange queſtion to ask at mid-night; Franciſco.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And that ſame falſe Franciſco in your abſence
Moſt leudly temped me to wrong your bed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: VVas ever woodcock catch'd thus?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Oh rogue, I'll go cut's throat ſleeping.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay I have fitted him moſt daintily.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Now, now, now, now, I am ſpitted.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I ſeem'd ſweet-heart to confent to him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A plague of ſeemings; I were beſt confeſs, and beg pardon.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And to make him ſure for, your revenge, I appointed
About this hour, the door left ope on purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ah!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: To meet me in the garden.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: All's well again.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Now ſweet-heart.
If thou would'ſt but ſteal down thither, thou mightſt catch him,
and ſnap the fool very finely.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Oh my ſweet birds-nie! what a wench have I of thee? Crede quod habes, & habes ſtill; and I had thought it poſſible to have been cuckloded, I had been cuckolded: I'll take my rapier as I go, ſirrah: and the night being dark, I'll ſpeak like thee, as if thou hadſt kept thy word. Oh Villian! nothing vexes me, but that he ſhould think I can he a cuckold, and have ſuch a Lady: do thou lie ſtill, and I'll bring thee his heart for thy Munkies break-faſt.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And would you part unkindly, and not kiſs me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I have no more manners then a gooſe; farewell
My chaſte delitious Doll: what may his life
Be compar'd to, that meets with ſuch a wife?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Piſh Pambo.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Here boy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Go meet him in the graden, and hark.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Excellent! I'll play my Lady, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Do't daintily.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: VVell I may hope for a Squires place, my father was a Coſtermonger.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: VVell now I ſee, as he who fain would know
The real ſtrain of goodneſs, may in her read it;
VVho can ſeem chaſte, and can be what ſhe ſeems:
So, who would ſee hells craft, in her may read it,
Who can ſeem too, but not be what ſhe ſeems:
In brief, put him to ſchool (would cheat the de'il of's right)
To a dainty ſmooth-fac'd female hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Here's a wife, Pambo!

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Now, Crede quod habes, & habes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why right man: let him believe he has horns, and he has 'em.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: To diſcover upon the pinch to ye!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Oh! you kind loving husband's like my ſelf,
What fortunes meet ye full but with ſuch wives!

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Fortune's i'th' faſhion of hay-forks.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sirra Pambo, thou ſhalt ſeldom ſee a harſh fellow have ſuch a wife, ſuch a fortunate wedding.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: He will go to hanging as ſoon.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No, no, we loving ſouls have all the fortunes;
There's Count Lorenzo for example now,
There's a ſweet coyle to morrow 'bout his wife:
He has two ſervants, that will take their oaths
They ſaw her diſhoneſt with his friend Count Philippo,
Nay in the very act: now what was't brought her to't, but his dogged uſage of her?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Nay ſhe never liv'd a good day with him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How ſhe goes flaunting too! ſhe muſt have a feather in her head, and a corke in her heel.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I that ſhews her light from head to heel, ſir; and who have heavier heads, then they whoſe wives have light heels? that feather confounds her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I ſhall ſo laugh to hear the Comical Hiſtory of the great Count Lorenzo's horns; but as I have ſuch a wife now, what a villain did I entertain to teach her muſick? 'has done her no good ſince he came, that I ſaw.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Hang him, 'has made herr a little perfect in prick-ſong, that's all; and it may be ſhe had skill in that, before you married her too.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: She could ſing at the firſt ſight, by this hand, Pambo.
But hark, I hear ſome-body.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: 'Tis he ſure, 'has a dreaming whore-maſters pace; pray let me practiſe my Ladies part, and counterfeit for her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Canſt thou imitate to th' life?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Can I? Oh wicked Francis!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Admirable! thou ſhalt do't.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Pray be you ready with your rapier to ſpit him then and I'll watch him a good turn, I warrant ye

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Here they are. If Pambo now comes off with his part neatly, the Comedy paſſes bravely: Who's there—Madam?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: I think this place lies too open to the air, Francis?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Delicate Pambo.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: And truely there's a great dew fallen to night,
The graſs is wondrous wet.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sweet rouge!

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Come Francis,
And let us ſport our ſelves in yonder ruſhes;
And being ſet, I'll ſmother thee with buſſes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Oh villain!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Hear me, Lady,
It is enough my Lord hath now a friend,
In theſe diſhoneſt days, that dares be honeſt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Nay for thy Lord, he's a meer coxcomb, Francis.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Out rogue!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis but your bad deſires that tell you ſo:
Can I contain a heart, or can that heart
Harbour a thought of injury gainſt him,
Under whoſe wing I ſafely ſtretch my penions?
Has he not nobly entertain'd me? ſtand I not
Next neighbour ſave your ſelf, unto his heart?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I by this hand doſt thou.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And ſhould I quit him thus? no, Lady, no.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Brave Frank!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I am too wiſe to fall in love with wo,
Much leſs with woman: I but took advantage
Of my Lords abſence, for your tryal Lady,
For fear ſome fellow (far hotter rein'd then I)
Might have ſought, and ſped; and I would be loath
A Lord ſo loving.—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Shalt have five leaſes, by theſe fingers.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Should have a Lady falſe.
Back Lady, to your yet unblemiſh'd bed;
Preſerve your honour, and your Lords Calves head.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Well Francis, you had been better: if I do not tell my Lord of this!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He has put him to't now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then I am loſt for ever,
You'll turn it all on me, I know; but ere
I'll live to wrong ſo good a Lord, or ſtand
The mark unto your malice, I will firſt
Fall on my ſword and periſh.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Hold, hold, hold man.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ha, who are you?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: One that has more humanity in him, then to ſee a proper fellow caſt himſelf away, I warrant thee: 'tis I, 'tis I man, I have heard all.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: And 'twas I play'd my Lady, to have ſnap'd ye.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Has ſhe been then ſo good to tell your honour?
Now am I worſe afflicted then before,
That ſhe ſhould thus outrun me, in this race of honeſty.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay ſh'as bob'd thee bravely; ſh'as a thouſand of theſe tricks, yfaith man; but howſoever, what I have found thee, I have found thee: hark in thine ear, ſhalt have five leaſes, and mine own Nag, when th'aſt a mind to ride

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Let me deſerve, ſir, firſt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Shalt have them: I know what I do, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I joy in ſuch a Lady.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay there's a couple of you, for a wife and a friend; ſhalt be no more my ſervant: I had thought to have made thee my Steward, but thou'rt too honeſt for the place, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: His ſuperfluity is my neceſſity; pray let me ha't, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I will talk with thee to morrow, Pambo; thou ſhalt have ſomething too; but I'll to bed: honeſt Francis, the deareſt muſt part, I ſee; I will ſo hug the ſweet raſcal that thinks every hour ten, till I come yonder! good night Frank, to bed Pambo. What delight in life.
sp.l: Can equal ſuch a friend and ſuch a wife?
So my dainty Doll, I come to thee.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: So a City-Night-Cap go with thee.—But ſhall
I not be thought on, for my nights ſervice?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Oh look ye, pray forget nor ye had ſomething.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Well, and pray do you remember I had nothing.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nothing! what's that?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Nothing before I had ſomething, I mean: ſo you are well return'd from Utopia.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You're very nimble ſir, good morrow.
sp.stage: A Bar ſet out. Enter the Duke of Verona, Pandulpho, Spinoſo, Jaſpro, Jovani, Lorenzo, Philippo, Abſtemia, a Guard, and two Slaves.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Call the accus'd to th' Bar.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We appear,
With acknowledg'd reverence to the preſence.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: We meet not
To build on circumſtances, but to come plainly
To the buſineſs that here plac'd us: Cozen Lorenzo,
You have free leave to ſpeak your griefs; but this
Deſire the Senate to obſerve, and neerly:
I come here not your kinſman neither, Madam,
Looking unto the greatneſs of your blood,
As you are fiſter to the Duke of Venice;
But as an equal Judge, I come to doom,
As circumſtances and proof informs.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Thus then,
(Great Sir, grave Lords, and honourable Auditors
Of my diſhonour) I affirm 'tis known
To th' ſignorie of Verona, the whole City,
Nay the great multitude without, that come
This day to hear unwilling truth, can witneſs,
How ſince my marriage with that woman (weepſt thou!
Oh truth, who would not look thee in a womans tears!
But ſhowers that fall too late, produce deer years)
All know that ſince our marriage, I have perform'd
So fairly all judicial wedlock-offices,
That malice knew not how at my whole actions
To make one blow: and to ſtrike home, I did rather
Honour her as a ſaint, ſir, then reſpect her
As ſhe was my wife: on pilgrimage I ſent
All my endeavours to the fair ſeeming ſhrine
Of her deſires, where they did offer daily
A plenal ſatisfaction, which ſhe ſeem'd
Reciprocally to return, pay'd back
As much obedience as I ſent of love:
But then the ſerpent ſtings, when like a dove.
Opinion feathers him: womens ſweet words
As far are from their hearts (though from their breſts
They flie) as Lapwings cries are from their neſts.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Oh you enveigh!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I would appear no ſatyre.
And for this man (how fain I would call him friend!)
I appeal to the whole ſtate, if at the fight
Betwixt Bizerta Gallies and your Grace,
Wherein you pleas'd to ſend me General there,
That he deſerv'd (let me not take from him
His merits meet confeſſion) but I was there
The man (the erring man) that crown'd his merit
With approbation and reward; brought him home,
Prefer'd him to thoſe graces you heap'd on him:
Wore him a neighbour to my heart, as lovers
Wear Jewls, left by their dead friends; I lock'd him
Into my heart, and double-bar'd him there
With reaſon and opinion: his extremities
Faſtn'd me more unto him, whilſt like an arch
Well built, by how much the more weight I bore,
I ſtand the ſtronger under him; ſo lov'd him,
That in his abſence ſtill mine ear became
A ſanctuary to his injar'd name.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: And what from hence infer you?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That 'twas baſe,
Baſe in the depth of baſeneſs, for this wife
So honour'd, and this ſmooth friend ſo belov'd,
To conſpire betwixt them my diſhonour.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: To ſtain my ſheets with luſt, a minutes theft:
To brand perpetually three faces; a husbands,
A wives, and friends.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Oh good my Lord,
Caſt out this devil from you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Oh good my Lady,
Keep not the devil within you, but confeſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hear me, great ſir; I will confeſs, Lorenzo,
And print thee down the fool of paſſion.

sp.speaker: Spin.
sp.l: Speak, ſir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis true, this boaſting man did thus erect me
In his opinion, plac'd me in his love,
Grac'd me with courteſies: Oh the craft of jealouſie!
As boys to take the bird about the pit,
Caſt wheat and chaff, contriving a neat train
To intice her to her ruine: ſo this friend
Falſer then City-oaths, it is not doubted,
Having ſo far indear'd me, when he came
To enjoy a fair wife, gueſt it impoſſible
For me to ſhare with him in all things elſe,
And not in her; for fair wives oft we ſee
Strike diſcord in ſweet friendſhips harmony:
And having no way to inſnare me ſo,
To ſeparate our loves, he ſeriouſly
Woo'd me to try his wife.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: 'Tis falſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis true,
By all that honeſt men may be believed by,
Three ſeveral witneſſes, I try'd her, by him urg'd to't,
Yet ſtill my truth not ſtarted, kept ſo conſtant,
That till this hour this Lady thus much knew not
I bore her brave reproofs: Oh when ſhe ſpake,
The ſaints ſure liſten'd, and at every point
She got the plauſe of Angels! now upon this,
This jealous Lord infers (and it may be but
To ſhun futurity) that I
(His betray'd friend) could not hold the cup,
But I muſt drink the poyſon: no, Lorenzo,
An honeſt man is ſtill an unmov'd rock,
Waſh'd whiter, but not ſhaken with the ſhock;
Whoſe heart conceives no ſiniſter device:
Fearleſs he playes with flames, and treads on ice.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Coſen, did you, as your friend here affirms,
Counſel him to theſe tryals?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You did.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Philippo, thou art fallen from a good man,
And haſt ta'en leave of modeſtie: let theſe my ſervants
(That incredulity ſhould be induction
To my more certain ſhame) let theſe ſpeak
And relate what they ſaw: they grew ſo publick,
My ſervants could diſcover them.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Speak, friends, be fearleſs;
And what you know, even to a ſillable,
Boldly confeſs.

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: Then know, great, ſir, as ſoon
As ere my Lord was gone to meet your Grace,
Signor Philippo and my Lady privately
Went up to her bed-chamber: we two ſuſpecting
What afterwards we found, ſtole ſoftly up,
And through the key-hole (for the door was lock'd)
We ſaw my Lady and Count Philippo there
Upon the bed, and in the very act,
As my Lord before affirm'd.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Canſt thou hear, heaven,
And withhold thy thunder?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My Lords one devil, ye know,
May poſſeſs three bodies.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Will you ſwear this, ſir?

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: I will, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Spin.
sp.l: And you?

sp.speaker: 2 Slave.
sp.l: I will, and dare, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Brave raſcals!

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Reach them the book.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Ye poor deluded men, Oh do not ſwear!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Think of the chain of pearl.

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: Give us the book:
That we affirm the truth, the whole truth,
And nothing but the truth, we ſwear.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Believe me, I am ſorry for the Lady.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How ſoon
Two ſouls more pretious then a pair of worlds
Are levell'd below deach!

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Oh hark! did you not hear it?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: VVhat, Lady?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: This hour a pair of glorious Towers are fallen;
Two goodly buildings beaten with a breath
Beneath the grave: you all have ſeen this day,
A pair of ſouls both caſt and kiſt away.

sp.speaker: Spin.
sp.l: VVhat cenſure gives your Grace?

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: In that I am kinſman
To the accuſer, that I might not appear
Partial in judgement, let it ſeem no wonder
If unto your gravicies I leave
The following ſentence: but as Lorenzo ſtands
A kinſman to Verona, ſo forget not,
Abſtemia ſtill is ſiſter unto Venice.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Miſery of goodneſs!

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Oh! Lorenzo Medico,
Abſtemia's lover once, when he did vow
And when I did believe; then when Abſtemia
Deny'd ſo many Princes for Lorenzo,
Then when you ſwore. Oh maids! how men can weep!
Print proteſtations on their breſts, and figh,
And look ſo truly, and then weep again,
And then proteſt again, and again diſſemble!
VVhen once enjoy'd, like ſtrange fights we grow ſtale,
And find our comforts like their wonder, fail.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh Lorenzo!
Look upon tears, each one of which well valued,
Is worth the pity of a King; but thou
Art harder far then Rocks, and canſt not prize
The pretious waters of truths injurd eyes.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Pleaſe your Grace proceed to cenſure.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Thus 'tis decreed, as theſe Lords have ſet down
Againſt all contradiction: Signor Philippo,
In that you have thus groſly, ſir, diſhonour'd
Even our blood it ſelf, in this rude injury
Lights on our kinſman, his prerogative
Implies death on your treſpaſs; but your merit
Of more antiquity then is your treſpaſs,
That death is blotted out, and in the place
Baniſhment writ, perpetual baniſhment
(On pain of death (if you return) for ever)
From Verona, and her ſignories.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Verona is kind.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Unto you, Madam,
This cenſure is alotted? Your high blood
Takes off the danger of the law, nay from
Even baniſhment it ſelf: this Lord your husband
Sues only for a legal fair divorce,
Which we think good to grant, the Church allowing:
And in that the injury
Chiefly reflects on him, he hath free lience
To marry when and whom he pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: I thank ye,
That you are favourable unto my Love,
Whom yet I love and weep for.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Farewell Lorenzo.
This breſt did never yet harbor a thought
Of thee, but man was in it, honeſt man:
There's all the words that thou art worth; of your Grace
I humbly thus take leave; farewel my Lords,
And laſtly farewel, thou faireſt of many,
Yet by far more unfortunate: look up
And ſee a crown held for thee; win it, and die
Lovers martyr, the ſad map of injury:
And ſo remember, ſir, your injur'd Lady
Has a brother yet in Venice.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Farewell Lorenzo,
VVhom my ſoul doth love. if you ere marry,
May you meet a good wife, ſo good, that you
May not ſuſpect her, nor may ſhe be worthy
Of your ſuſpition: and if you hear hereafter
That I am dead, enquire but my laſts words,
And you ſhall know that to the laſt I lov'd you;
And when you walk forth with your ſecond choyce,
Into the pleaſant fields, and by chance talk of me,
Imagine that you ſee me lean and pale,
Strewing your paths with flowers: and when in bed
You caſt your arms about her happy ſide,
Think you ſee me ſtand with a patient look,
Crying, All hail, you lovers, live and proſper;
But may ſhe never live to pay my debts:
If but in thought ſhe wrong you, may ſhe die
In the conception of the injury.
Pray make me wealthy with one kiſs: farewel, ſir:
Let it not grieve you when you ſhall remember
That I was innocent: not this forget,
Though innocence here ſuffer, ſigh and groan,
She walks but thorow thorns to finde a throne.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Break up the Court, and Coſen learn this reed;
VVho ſtabs Truths boſom, makes an Angel bleed.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The ſtorm upon my breſt, ſir.

div.head: Actus Tertius.
div.stage: Enter Lodovico Jaſpro, Jovani and Clown.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: DId Chronicle ever match this couple, genetlemen?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: You maks us wonder,
That both ſhould ſeem to yeild to the temptation,
And both ſo meet in one reſolved goodneſs,
Unknown to one another!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: There lies the jeſt on't. Sirrah Pambo, I do but think and ſhe had met him in the gardon, how ſhe would have • atled him.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: And ruffled him too, ſir; the Camomile would have been better for it many a day after.

sp.speaker: Jov.
sp.l: Such an honeſt minded ſervant, where ſhall one finde?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Servant? my ſworn brother, man, he's too honeſt for an office he'll never thrive in't: ye have few ſervants will deal ſo mercifully with their Lords.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: A wife why ſhe's a ſaint, one that ever bears
A good ſound ſoul about her.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Yes, when ſhe wears her new ſhooes.

sp.speaker: Jov.
sp.l: Shall we ſee her, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: VVhere is ſhe, Pambo?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: VValking a turn or two i'th' garden with Franciſco, ſir:
I go call her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No, no, no; let her alone, 'tis pity indeed to part them, they are ſo well match'd: was he not reading to her?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: No, ſir, ſhe was weeping to him: ſhe heard this morning that her confeſſor father Jacomo was dead.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Father Jacomo dead?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why now ſhall not we have her eat one bit this five days.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: She'll munch the more in a corner, that's the Puritans faſt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay do but judge of her my Lords by one thing; whereas moſt of our dames go to confeſſion but once a month; ſome twice a quarter, and ſome but once a year, and that upon conſtraint too; ſhe never miſſes twice a Week.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: 'Tis wonderful.

sp.speaker: Jov.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſign ſhe keeps all well at home: thy are even
With the whole world, that ſo keep touch with heaven.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay, I told ye, ye ſhould finde no Philippo of Franciſco.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: And I remember I told your honour, you ſhould finde no Abſtemia of my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nor no Lorenzo of my ſelf; he was ever a melancholy ſtubborn fellow, he kept her in too much, and ſee what comes on't; I give my wife her will; and ſee what comes on't too.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Nay ſir, there is two come on't, and a man could diſcover 'em.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Two what, I prethee?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: It may be two babies, ſir, for they come commonly with giving a woman her will.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I'd laugh at that, yfaith boy: but who has ſhe now for her confeſſor?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: She looks for one they call him father Antony, ſir, and he's wiſh'd to her by Madona Luſſurioſa.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: There's another modeſt ſoul too, never without a holy man at her elbow: but here comes one out-weighs them all: Why how now chick! weeping ſo faſt? this is the fault of moſt of our Ladies, painting, weeping for their ſins I ſhould ſay, ſpoils their faces.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: ſweet Madam!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Look, look, look, loving ſoul, he weeps for company.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: And I ſhall laugh our-right by and by.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Oh that good man!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why bird?

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Be patient, Lady.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Would he go to heaven without his zealous pupil?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: It may be he knew not your mind, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He knew my mind well enough.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Why then it may be he knew you could not hold out for the journey; pray do not ſet us all a crying—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Prethee ſweet birds-nye be content.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes, yes, content, when you too leave my company?
No one comes neer me; ſo that were it not
For modeſt ſimple Francis here.—

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: As modeſt as a gib cat at midnight.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That ſometimes reads
Vertuous books to me; were it not for him,
I might go look content: but 'tis no matter,
No body cares for me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay prethee Doll; pray gentlemen comfort her.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Now is the devil writing an encomium upon cunning cuckold-makers.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You have been harſh to her of late, I fear, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: By this hand, I turn'd not from her all laſt night: what ſhould a man do?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Come, this is but a ſweet obedient ſhower,
To bedew the lamented grave of her old father.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: He thinks the devil's dead too.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: But 'tis no matter, were I ſuch a one
As the Count Lorenzo's Lady, were I ſo graceleſs
To make you wear a pair of wicked horns,
You would make more reckoning of me—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Weep again? ſhe'll cry out her eyes, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: No I warrant yee; remember the two lines your
Honour read laſt night.
sp.stage: A Womans Eye, 'S Aprils Duſt, no ſooner wet but dry.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Good pigs-nye! Frank, prethee walk her t'other turn i'th' garden, and get her a ſtomach to her ſupper; we'll be with ye preſently, wench.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nay when ye pleaſe—But why ſhould I go from ye?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Loving ſoul! prethee Frank take her away.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pray let me kiſs ye firſt Come Francis,
No body cares for us—At the door Francis kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well, there goes a couple; where ſhall a man match ye indeed? Hark Pambo!

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Did you obſerve?

sp.speaker: Jov.
sp.l: They kiſt.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: And intreat Madona Luſſurioſa to ſup with us, as you go, tell her my Lady's never well, but in her company.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: What if your honour invited the Count Lorenzo? he'll be ſo melancholy now his Lady and he are parted!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Pray do as you are bid, kind ſir, and let him alone; I'll have no cuckold ſup in my houſe to night.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Tis a very hot evening, your honour will ſup in the garden then.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes, marry will I, ſir; what's that to you?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Why, your honour was ever as good as your word: keep the cuckolds out of door, and lay a cloath for my Lord in the Arbour, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I have been this three months about a project.

sp.speaker: Jov.
sp.l: What is't, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why I intend to compoſe a pamphlet of all my wives vertues, put them in print, and dedicate them to the Duke, as orthodoxal directions againſt he marries.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.p: 'Twill give him apt inſtructions, when he does marry, to pick out ſuch a woman.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Pick her, where will he pick her? as the Engliſh proverb ſays, He may as ſoon finde a needle in a bottle of hay: would I know what ſins ſhe has committed, I would ſet them down all one with another; they would ſerve as ſoyles to her vertues: but I do think ſhe has none; d'ye think ſhe has any, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Jov.
sp.l: Oh none ſir but has ſome!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I, pidling ones it may be, a when a pin pricks her fingers to cry at ſight on't, and throw't away; but for other matters.—

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.p: Now I think on't, ſir, I have a device newly begotten, that if you be ſo deſirous to be reſolv'd of her perfections, 'twill be an apt means for your intelligence.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: That will be excellent, and then my book grounded upon mine own experience, the report of my judgement in the choyce of a woman, will ſell them off faſter than the Compoſitor can ſet the Letters together.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: We will diſcourſe it as we go; mean time, Sir,
Let this prepare the path to your conſtruction.
Conceipt and confidence are juglers born:
One grafts in air, t'other hides the real born.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well, he that believes he has horns, has horns;
And Crede quod habes & habes, ſhall be my Motto.

sp.speaker: Spin.
sp.l: The powers of Venice upon our Confines!

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Yes, Seignor Philippo, it ſeems, having poſſeſt him
With the paſſages that paſt upon his Siſter;
Embaſſadors were diſpatch'd to Bergamo,
Where then his Forces lay; who thus return'd,
That he came not a publick foe unto Verona,
But to require juſtice againſt Count Lorenzo,
To approve his ſiſter innocent.

sp.speaker: Spin.
sp.l: What witneſs,
Proof or apparent circumſtance builds he
His bold attempt upon?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: He ſays, beſides
The honour of Philippo, he has proof
So unreſiſtable to affirm the plot
Of Count Lorenzo, that he only crav'd
(Hoſtages being rendered for their ſafe returns)
Here in the Senate-chamber, the fair tryal
Might publickly be cenſur'd: and by this
They are at hand.
sp.stage: Enter at one Door, Duke of Venice, Philippo and Lords: At the other, Duke of Verona, Jaſpno, Jovani, Lorenzo guarded. A bar ſet out. The 1 Slave.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Fair ſir, the preſence is levell'd for your grevances.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Firſt ſummon to the bar the Count Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Lorenzo Medico, ſtand to the bar.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I do ſtand to the bar.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I come not here, witneſs the good mans comfort, to adde one ſtep
Unto my territories: and though I burthen
The neighbour-boſom of my confines with
The weight of armour, or do wound your breſt
(My Dukedoms neer next neighbour) with the hoofs
Of war-apparell'd horſes; 'tis not to ſeek
For martial honours, but for civil juſtice.
Conceave mine honour wounded, a ſiſters ſhame
Is an unpleaſant ſpot upon our Arms:
Yet that we come not here to ſanctifie
A ſiſters ſin; for if ſhe ſo be prov'd,
Shame ſleep within her epitaph, and brand her;
Let Bears and Wol • es that Angels Face confound,
Gives goodneſs ſuch a foul unfriendly wound:
But if ſhe chaſte be prov'd, what balin can cure
A wounded name? As he that not inflicts
The bitter ſtraok of law upon the ſtrumper,
Fattens the ſad afflictions of a thouſand:
So who but ſtains an honeſt womans name,
Plagues are yet kept for him, ſteel is no defence
For the unclean tongue injures innocence.
I affirm my ſiſter wrong'd, wrong'd by this man,
This that has wrong'd pure judgement, and thrown poyſon
Upon the face of truth, and upon him
I ſecek a ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I reply:
The law muſt give you ſatisfaction,
That juſtly did divorce us: I appeal
To the whole Conſiliadory, it equal law
In her progreſſion went a ſtep aſtray,
Either by proof or information:
Let the Duke ſpeak (not as he is my kinſman)
If I produc'd not legally in Court,
Beſides mine own aſſertion (which even reaſon
Grounded on probability) two of my ſervants
That upon oath affirm'd they ſaw your ſiſter
Even in the very act of ſin and ſhame
VVith that Philippo there: blame me not then, ſir,
If I return an error to your cauſe,
Reaſon (the Baſe where on we build the laws)
You injure in this action; give her the lye:
VVho dares not build his faith upon his eye?
They ſwore what they did ſee; and men ſtill fear,
(Reaſon concludes) what they not ſee, to ſwear,

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: You hear my kinſmans anſwer.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And 'tis requiſite
That you produce your authour: it is held
Meer madneſs on a hill of ſand to build.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The foundation-work is mine, and that I anſwer:
He builds on truth, the good mans miſtris,
And not in the ſanctuary.
Of this injui'd brothers power, but the integrity
And glory of the cauſe: I throw the pawn
Of my afflicted honour, and on that
I openly affirm your abſent Lady
Chaſtitie's well-knit abſtract, ſnow in the fall,
Purely refin'd by the bleak Northern blaſt,
Not freer from a ſoyl, the thoughts of Infants;
But little neerer heaven: And if theſe Princes
Pleaſe to permit, before their guilty thoughts
Injure another hour upon the Lady,
My right drawn ſword ſhall prove it.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Upon my knee, ſir,
(How my ſoul dances!) humbly I intreat
Your grant to his requeſt; fight with Philippo
I'th' midſt of flame, or peſtilence in a Cave,
VVhere Baſiliskes do breed.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: VVe muſt take counſell,
The price of blood is pretious.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Blood deſires burthen:
The price of Truth is precious: for all the fights
I have fought for you on land; the fears at lea,
Where I have tug'd with tempeſts, ſtood ſtorms at midnight,
Out-ſtar'd the flaring lightning; and the next morning
Chas'd the unruly ſtubborn Turk with thunder:
For all the bullers I have bravely ſhot,
And ſent death ſinging to the ſlaughter, Sir

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What ſhould a ſouldier do with peace? remember
Mine Honour lies a bleeding, and in mine yours;
Her wide wound inward bleeds; and while you cry peace,
Shame wars upon my Name: Oh rather kill me,
Then caſt me to this ſcandal.

sp.speaker: Spin.
sp.l: The doubtful cauſe,
With ſuch dare approv'd, you may permit it.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Your requeſt is granted, Coze

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You have now, Sir, breath'd
Freſh air in the face of fainting Honour
Rapiers of fair equality.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Look with what cunning
The ſpider, when ſhe would ſhare the fly, doth weave;
VVith neater Art appearances deceive.
Stay, as you ſaid, ſir, blood is a pretious price.
Let me but ſee the men produc'd, who ſwore
They ſaw them in the ſhameful act: and then
Farewel a ſiſter and her honour.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Produce your ſervants, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Plague of this change, here's one of them; the t' other
In that I threaten'd him for ſome neglect,
The next day ran away.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Did you ſir, ſwear
You ſaw our ſiſter and this gentleman
In this baſe act of ſin?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Fear nothing.

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: To deny truth, is more dangerous then to diſpleaſe a Duke:
I ſaw it and did ſwear it.

sp.speaker: Venice.
sp.l: But here comes one,
VVill ſwear you ſaw it not, and are forſworn.

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: 'Sfoot, Stratzo!

sp.speaker: Spin.
sp.l: This is the other fellow took his oath.

sp.speaker: Vere.
sp.l: VVhat come you here to ſay, ſir?

sp.speaker: 2 Slave.
sp.l: That we ſwore falſely, may it pleaſe your Grace,
Hyr'd by my Lord with gifts and promiſes:
And as I now have ſpoke the muth, ſo heaven
Forgive my former perjury.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Hear you, coſen?

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: VVould you would ſay ſomething; I have nettles in my breeches.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Now, now, I hope your eyes are open, Lords,
The bed of ſnakes is broak, the tricks's comes about,
And here's the knot i'th' ruſh: good heaven, good heaven,
That craft in ſeeking to put on diſguiſe,
Should ſo diſcover her ſelf!

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Explain your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Now ſee ſir, where this ſcorpion lutks to ſting
Mine honour unto death: this noble Dule
By nature is ingag'd to defend a ſiſter:
And to this Duke ſo ingag'd, this malitious Lord
(For ſin ſtill ha her ſcourger) makes repair,
And prepoſſeſſes him with that ſuppos'd innocence
Of an injur'd ſiſter; which he had hir'd this Slave
To follow him, and affirm, and layes the cauſe
To ſcruple, and to conſcience: they did conſent
To ſteal belief by ſeeming accident.
Sin Jugler-like, caſts ſin before our eyes;
Craft ſometimes ſteals the wonder of the wiſe.
VVith an equal hand now weigh me, and if I want
A grain of honour, tear me from your blood,
And caſt me to contempt.

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: My Lord would have made an excellent ſtate-ſophiſter.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: In what a ſtrange dilemma judgement ſits,
Charm'd to her chair with wonder.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Shall I have juſtice?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Yes, in that this fellow ſwears for the Duke:
Reach him the book, you ſhall ſee him again
Take the former oath.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: This doubt muſt be ſo ended;
If it give not ſatisfaction, ſend back our hoſtage,
You have fair regreſs to your forces: but
The blood remains on you; and ſtill remember
The price of blood is pretious.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let us end it.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Oh what a Combat Honour holds with Conſcience!
Reach him the book; and if thou falſe doſt ſay,
May thine own tongue, thine own foul heart betray

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: Amen, ſay I:
Give me the book, my oath muſt end all then.

sp.speaker: Spin.
sp.l: It muſt.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Now you ſhall hear him ſwear,
He ſaw them both in the baſe act.

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: Nay I ſwear
They are now both ſeen in the baſe act.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſtrange oath.

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: 'Tis true though.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: True, villain! are both now ſeen in the baſe act?

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: Yes, both.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: VVhich both?

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: You and I, ſir.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: Both you and I are ſeen in the baſe act,
Slandering ſpotleſs honour; an act ſo baſe,
The barbarous Moor would bluſh at.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: D'ye hear him now?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Out Slave, wilt thou give ground too? fear works upon 'em.
Did you not both here ſwear i'th' Senate-chamber
You ſaw them both diſhoneſt?

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: Then we ſwore true, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I told you 'twas but fear.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Swore ye true then, ſir, when ye ſwore
Ye both ſaw them diſhoneſt?

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: Yes marry did we, ſir:
For we were both two villains when we ſaw them,
So we ſaw them diſhoneſt.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Heaven, thou art equal!

sp.speaker: 1 Slave.
sp.l: This is a jealous Lord, his Lady chaſte,
A rock of chriſtal not more clear: this gentleman
Baſely abus'd: this great Prince diſhonour'd;
And ſo we kneel for mercy.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: You have redeem'd it:
Depart, prove honeſt men: that I ſhould bear
Diſhonour in my blood!

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Much injur'd Lady!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: VVhat juſtice, ſir, belongs unto the injur'd?

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Firſt, witneſs heaven, I tear thee from my blood,
And caſt thee off a ſtranger: Aſſume you, ſir,
(Since the great cauſe is yours) my ſeat of juſtice,
And ſentence this foul homicide; it muſt be,
And ſuddenly; he will infect the air elſe:
Proceed, great ſir, with rigor, whilſt I ſtand by
And do adore the ſentence.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Anſwer, Lorenzo,
Art thou not guilty?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Give me my merit, death;
Princes can build and ruine with one breath.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: The cauſe may ſeem to merit death, in that
Two ſouls were hazarded, a Princeſs iame,
A Duke diſhonour'd, and a noble Lord
Wounded in reputation: but ſince ſhe lives,
And that no blood was ſpilt (though ſomething dearer)
Mercy thus far ſtretches her ſilver wings
Over your treſpaſs, we do baniſh you,
Both from our Dukedomes Limits and your own:
If you but ſet a daring foot upon them
Whileſt life lends you ability to ſtand,
You fall into the pit of death, unleſs
You ſhall finde out our moſt unfortunate ſiſter,
And bring her to our Court.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You ſir are merciful!

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: This let me adde, in that you have made impartial juſtice, ſir,
Princes ſhould puniſh vice in their own blood:
Until you finde that excellent injur'd Lady,
Upon this gentleman, who hath ſuffer'd for you,
We confer your lands, revenues, and your place;
That during three days ſtay within our confines
It ſhall be death, to any that relieves you,
But as they do a begger at their door.
So caſt him from our preſence.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your dooms are juſt!
Oh love, thy firſt deſtruction is diſtruſt!

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: For you, fair ſir, until we ſhall hear tydings
Of your moſt injur'd ſiſter, pleaſe you to call
My Court your own, conceive it ſo: where live,
Two partnersin one paſſion we will be,
And ſweeten ſorrow with a ſympathy.
sp.stage: Enter Lodovico like a Fryer, Jaſpro and Jovani.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What, am I fitted, gallants? am I fitted?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: To th' life, able to cheat ſuſpition, and ſo like
Father Antony the confeſſor, that I proteſt
There's not more ſemblance in a pair of egges.

sp.speaker: Jov.
sp.l: An apple cut in half, is not ſo like.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: VVell, of Lords you're mad Lords to counſel me to this; but now in this habit ſhall I know the very core of her heart, all her little pedling ſins, which will ſhew in my book as foils to her giant-bodied vertues.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: That will be admirable!

sp.speaker: Jov.
sp.l: We'll ſtep aſide: by this ſhe's upon coming.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: We ſhall know all.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Reveal confeſſion: but go your ways; as much as may lawfully be reveal'd, we'll laugh as, at next meeting

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Come, let's be gone: but once upon a time, ſir,
A begger found a larks neſt, and o'er-joy'd
At his ſuddain glut, for he thought 'twas full of young ones,
Looking, they were all gone; he was forc'd again to beg,
For he found in the Larks neſt a Serpents egge;
So much good d'ye ſir.—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well, thou ſurpaſſeſt all the courtiers in theſe pretty ones; if a man had the wit to underſtand them—Yonder ſhe comes; I can hardly forbear bluſhing, but that for diſcovering my ſelf.
sp.l: Right reverend habit, I honour thee
With a Sons obedience, and do but borrow thee,
As men would play with flyes, who i'th' midſt of modeſt mirth
With care preſerve themſelves.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Hail holy Father.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Welcome my chaſte daughter.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Death having taken good father Jacomo,
Upon the plenal and approv'd report
Of your integrity and upright dealing—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Delicate Doll.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I have made a modeſt choyce of you, grave ſir,
To be my ghoſtly father: and to you I fall▪
For abſolution.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Empty then, my daughter,
That veſſel of your fleſh, of all the dregs,
VVhich (ſince your laſt confeſſion clear'd you) have
Taken a ſetled habitation in you;
And with a powerful ſweet acknowledgment,
Hunt out thoſe ſpirits which haunt that houſe of fleſh
Tears makes dry branches flouriſh green and freſh.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Since laſt I confeſt, then I do confeſs,
My firſt ſin was, that my Taylor bringing home
My laſt new gown, having made the ſleeves too ſlanting;
In an unchriſtian paſſion I did bid
The devil take him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: That was ſomething 〈◊〉 , dear daughter
Yet the more pardonable, for it may be your taylor
Lyes in hell, night by night: pray to your ſecond.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Next, in a more ſavage rage, my chamber-maid
Putting a little ſaffom in her ſtarch,
I moſt unmercifully broak her head.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'Twas raſhly done too: but are ye ſure, dear daughter,
The maids head was not broak before?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, no, ſir, ſhe came to me with neer a crack about her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Theſe will be brave ſins to mix with her vertues; why they will make no more ſhew then three or four bayliffs amongſt a company of honeſt men. Theſe ſins, my Dove-like daughter, are out of contradiction venial, trivial and light: have you none of greater growth?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Oh Yes, ſir, one!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: One? what ſhould that be; I wonder?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: One yet remains behind,
Of weight and conſequence: the ſame order
Heralds preſcribe in ſhews, I now obſerve
In placing of my ſins; as there inferiours
(Becauſe the laſt lives freſheſt in our memories)—
Far more the perſons of great note, ſo laſt
My great ſin comes to obliterate thoſe paſt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sh'as trod ſome chicken to death, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Hear me, and let a bluſh make you look red,
Unſeemly I have abus'd my husbands bed.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You did ill to drink too hard ere you went to bed.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Alas, ſir, you miſtake me; I have lain
With another man, beſides my husband

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay the ſame way I uſe to lye with him,
But not altogether ſo often.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: VVhy then Crede quod habes, & habes; I will believe I have hornes, for I have 'em: 'Sfoot, a woman, I perceive, is a neat Herald, ſhe can quarter her husbands coat with Butchers Arms at pleaſure: but I have a penance for your pure whoreſhip: you are ſomewhat broad, are you not with childe, daughter?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes, yes, ſure 'twas that nights work.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How know you that?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Alas, by experience, ſir: the kind fool my husband
VViſhes all well; but like a light piece of gold,
He's taken for more then he weighs.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: VVith child! there's charges too: at other ſide, there ſhould follow
A zealous exhortation: but great affairs
That brook no ſtay, make me be brief, remembring
Lawful neceſſity may diſpence with ceremony:
You are ingenuouſly ſorry?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes indeed ſir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And reſolve to fall no more ſo?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No in truth ſir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I then pronounce you here abſolv'd: now for your penance.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: As the fact in you ſeems ſtrange, ſo blame me not
If your penance be as ſtrange: you may wonder it;
But it is wondrous eaſie in performance,
But as your penance I enjoyn it: nay now I remember,
In an old French Authentick Author, his book
Titled, De Satisfactione, I read the ſame
Enjoyn'd a Lady of Dauphin. 'Tis no holy faſt,
No devout prayer, nor no zealous pilgrimage;
'Tis out of the preſcrib'd road.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Let it be
So ſtrange, ſtory ne'er matcht the injunction, I do vow
The plenal ſtrict performanc • .

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Liſten to me.
Soon at night (ſo rumour ſpreads it through the City)
The two great Dukes of Venice and Verona
Are feaſted by your Lord, where a mask's intended.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That's true, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Now when ye all are ſet round about the Table
In depth of ſilence, you ſhall confeſs theſe words
Aloud to your husband: YOU ARE NOT THIS CHILD'S FATHER;
And 'cauſe my orders bar me ſuch inquiſition,
You ſhall ſay, Such a man lay with me, naming the party
Was partner in your ſin.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Good ſir!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: This is your penance, I enjoyn you; keep it,
You are abſolv'd; break it, you know the danger of it: god-buy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Oh good ſir ſtay, never was penance of more ſhame then this.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You know the danger of the breach as to us,
'Tis the ſhameful loſs of our religious orders if we reveal.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: For heaven ſake,
Enjoyn me firſt upon my knees to creep
From Verona to Loretto.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: That's nothing.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nothing indeed to this: is this your penance ſo wondrous eaſie in performance?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'Tis irrevocable.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I am ſilent: your new penance nay meet a new performance: farewel, ſir.
You are the cruelſt ere confeſt me before.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And this the trick to catch a near pure whore.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: HEre miſerable deſpis'd Abſtemia,
In Millain let thy miſery take breath,
Wearied with many ſufferings. Oh Lorenzo!
How far in love I am with my affliction,
Becauſe it calls thee father! unto this houſe,
Where gentlewomen lodge, I was directed;
But I here diſcover
Strange actions cloſely carried in this houſe.
Great perſons (but not good) here nightly revel
In ſurfets, and in riots, yet ſo carried,
That the next day the place appears a ſanctuary,
Rather then ſins foul receptable; theſe ways
Have to me ſtill been ſtrangers; but Lorenzo,
Thou couldſt not though believe it: Oh jealouſie!
Loves eclipſe, thou art in thy diſeaſe,
A wild mad patient, wondrous hard to pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yonder ſhe walks mumbling to her ſelf; the Prince Antonio has bleſt her with's obſervation; and ye win her but to him, your houſe bears the bell away; accoſt her quaintly.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I warrant thee, Morbo Madona, Timpania has effected wonders of more weight then a maiden-head: have I ruin'd ſo many City-Citadels, to let in. Court-martialiſts; and ſhall this Country-Cottage hold our? I were more fit for a Cart then a Coach, then yfaith: how now Millicent, how d'ye this morning?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: VVell, I do thank ſo good a Landlady.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: But hark you, Mill, is the door cloſe, Morbo?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: As a Uſurers conſcience. Grace was coming in, till ſhe ſaw the door ſhut upon her▪

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'll ſet Grace about her buſineſs, and I come to her: is here any work for Grace, with a wannion to her? we ſhall have Eaves-droppers, ſhall we?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Chaſtity guard me, how I tremble▪

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Come hither miſtreſs Millicent; fie, how you let your hair hang about your ears too? how do you like my houſe, Mill?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: VVell, indeed well.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay I know a woman may riſe here in one month, and ſhe will her ſelf: but truths truth, I know yoo ſee ſomething, as they ſay, and ſo forth. Did you ſee the gallant was here laſt till 12?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: VVhich of them mean you? here was many.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: VVhich? he in the white feather that ſupp'd in the gallery, was't not white Morbo?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: As a Ladies hand, by theſe five fingers.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: White? no, no, 'twas a tawny, now I remember.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: As a Gipſie, by this hand; it look'd white by candle▪ light though.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: That luſty ſpringal Millicent, is no worſe man
Then the Duke of Millains Son.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: His excellent carriage ſpoke him of noble birth.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And this ſame Dukes ſon, loves you, Millicent.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Now heaven defend me!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What from a Dukes ſon? many come up with a murren, from whence came you: tto, ha?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Thus nice Grace was at firſt, and you remember.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I would have ye know, houſwife, I could have taken my Coach and fetch'd him one of the beſt pieces in Millain, and her husband ſhould have look'd after me, that's neighbours might have noted, and cry'd farewel Naunt, commend me to mine Uncle.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: And yet from theſe perfum'd fortunes, heaven defend you.
