sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Perfum'd indeed.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
Perfum'd! I am a Pander, a Rogue, that hangs together
like a beggers rags, by geometry: if there were not three Ladies ſwore yeſterday that my miſtres perfum'd the coach! ſo they were fain to unbrace all ſhe ſide-parts, to take in freſh air.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: He tells you true, I keep no 〈…〉 a company, I warrant ye; we vent no breath'd ware here.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.p: But have ye ſo many ſeveral women to anſwer ſo many men that come?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I'll anſwer that by demonſtration: have ye not obſerv'd the variation of a Cloud? ſometimes 'twill be like a Lyon, ſometimes like a horſe, ſometimes a Caſtle, and yet ſtill a Cloud.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why ſo can we make one wench one day look like a Country-wench, another day like a Citizens wife, another day like a Lady; and yet ſtill be a punk.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: What ſhall become of me? Oh the curſe
Of goodneſs, to leave one wo for a worſe!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Morrow ſweet Madam; Oh look how like the Sun behind a Cloud, the beams do give intelligence it is there.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: You're reciprocal welcome, ſir,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What have ye not brought this young wild haggard to the lure yet?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Faith ſir, ſhe's a little irregular yet; but time, that turns Citizens Caps into Court-periwigs, will bring the wonder about.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Bleſs you, ſweet miſtres.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: 'Sfoot here's the Prince, I ſmell thunder.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Your Grace is moſt methodically welcome: you muſt pardon my vareity of phraſe, the Courtiers e'en cloy us with good words.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: A gentleman of Ferrara, ſir, one Pedro Sebaſtiano.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: And do ye ſet her out to ſale, I charg'd ye reſerve for me alone?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Indeed ſir.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Pox of your deeds.—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Oh my Sciatica!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Sirrah, you perfum'd raſcal. [Kicks Philippo, they draw.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Nay good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Good ſir, 'tis one of the Dukes chamber.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let him be of the devils chamber.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Sirrah, leave the houſe, or I will ſend thee out with thunder.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.l: Good ſir, 'tis madneſs here to ſtand him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Sfootkickt? pray that we meet no more again, ſir;
Still keep heaven about you.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: What ere thou art, a good man ſtill go with thee.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Will you beſtow a caſt of your profeſſions?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: We are vaniſh'd, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: This 'tis to dream of rotten glaſſes, Morbo.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: O what ſhall become of me? in his eye
Murder and luſt contends.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Nay flie not, you ſweet,
I am not angry with you, indeed I am not:
Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Yes, ſir, report hath given intelligence
You are the Prince, the Dukes ſon.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Both in one.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Report ſure
Spoke but her native language; you are none of either.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Were you the Prince, you would not ſure be ſlav'd
To your bloodspaſſion: I do crave your pardon
For my rough language; truth hath a forehead free,
And in the tower of her integrity,
Sits an unvanquiſh'd virgin: can you imagine
'Twill appear poſſible you are the Prince?
VVhy when you ſet your foot firſt in this houſe,
You cruſh'd obedient duty unto death,
And even then fell from you your reſpect:
Honour is like a goodly old houſe, which
If we repair not ſtill with vertues hand,
Like a Citadel being madly rais'd on ſand,
It falls, is ſwallow'd and not found.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: If you rail upon the place, prethee how cam'ſt thou hither?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: By treacherous intelligence: honeſt men ſo
In the way ignorant, through theeves purlewes go.
Are you ſon to ſuch a noble Father?
Send him to's grave then
Like a white Almond-tree, full of glad days,
VVith joy that he begot ſo good a ſon.
Oh ſir, methinks I ſee ſweet Majeſty
Sit with a mourning ſad face full of ſorrows
To ſee you in this place: this is a cave
Of Scorpions and of Dragons; Oh turn back!
Toads here ingender, 'tis the ſtream of death;
The very air poyſons a good mans breath.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Within there!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Is my Caroach at door?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And your horſes too, ſir; ye found her pliant.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Y'are rotten hoſpitals hung with greaſie ſattin.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Ah!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Came this nice piece from Naples, with a pox to her?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And ſhe has not Neapolitanis'd him, I'll be flead for't.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Let me borrow goodneſs from thy lip: farewel:
Here's a new wonder, I have met heaven in hell.
sp.stage: Enter Venice, Vorona, Lodovico, Pandulpho, Iaſpro.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Is this your chaſt religious Lady?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay good my Lord, let it be carried with a ſilent reputation, for the credit of the concluſion; as all here are privy to the paſſage, I do deſire not to be laugh'd at, till after the Mask and we are all ready: I have made bold with ſome of your Graces gentlemen, that are good dancers.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: 'Tis one of my greateſt wonders, credit me,
To think what way ſhe will deviſe here openly,
To perform her ſo ſtrict penance.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: It buſies me, believe me too.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Ye may ſee now, ſir, how poſſible 'tis for a cunning
Lady, to make an Aſs of a Lord too confident.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: An Aſs! I will prove a contented Cuckold the wiſeſt man in's company.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: How prove you that, ſir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Becauſe he knows himſelf.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Very well brought in.
Is all our furniture fit, againſt the morning,
To go for Millain?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Ready, and like your Grace.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: We are given to underſtand, the injur'd Princeſs,
Whom Count Lorenzo and noble Philippo
Are (unknow to one another) gone in ſearch of,
Hath been ſeen there diſguis'd: ſtrict inquiſition
From the Duke himſelf ſhall ere many daies
Give our hopes a ſatisfaction.
sp.stage: Enter Dorothea, Ladies, Franciſco and Clown.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: The Ladies, ſir; Franciſco keeps before, ſir;
And Pambo keeps all well behind.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes, there's devout lechery between hawk and buzzard: but pleaſe ye ſet the Ladies: the Mask attends your Grace.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Come Ladies ſit: Madona Dorothea,
Your ingenious Lord hath ſuddenly prepar'd us
For a conceited Mask, and himſelf it ſeems
Playes the preſenter.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Now fie upon this vanity:
A profane Mask! chaſtity keep us, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: What, from a Mask? whereon grounds your wiſh?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Marry my Lord upon experience.
I heard of one, once brought his wife to a Mask,
As chaſte as a cold night; but poor unfortunate fellow
He loſt her in the throng, and ſhe poor ſoul
Came home ſo cruſh'd next morning!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: 'Las that was ill:
But women will be loſt againſt their will.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Silence, the Maſquers enter.
sp.stage: Enter Lodovico, Clown and Maſquers; a Stag, a Rom, a Bull and a Goat.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Look to me, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Do not ſhake, they'll think th'art out.—A Mark.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: A Mask, or no Mask; no Mask but a By-clap;
And yet a Mask yclep'd a City-Night-Cap.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And conve—

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: And conveniently for to keep off ſcorns,
Conſiderately the cap is hedg'd with hornes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: We inſnuate.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Speak a little louder.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: We inſinuate.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: We inſinuate by this Stag and Ram ſo pritty,
With Goat and Bull, Court, Country, Camp and City.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Cuckold

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Cuckold my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'Tis the firſt word of your next line.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Oh—Cuckold begins with C. And is't not ſport?
Then C. Begins with Country, Camp and Court:
But here's the fine figary of our Poet,
That one may wear this Night-Cap, and not know it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why chicken, ſhall they make ſuch an Aſs of thee? good your Grace, can a woman indure to ſee her loving husband wear horns in's own houſe?

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Pray Lady, 'tis but in jeſt.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: In jeſt? nay for the jeſt ſake, keep then on ſweet bird.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Now to our Masks name: but firſt, be it known-a,
When I name a City, I only mean Verona.
sp.p: Thoſe two lines are extempore, I proteſt, ſir; I brought them in becauſe here are ſome of other Cities in the room that might ſnuff pepper elſe.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: You have fairly ta'en that fear off; pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your kindeſt men.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Your kindeſt men moſt cuckolds are, Oh pity!
And where have women moſt their will, Oh City!
Sick for a Night-Cap, go to cuckolds luck;
Who thrives like him, who hath the daintieſt duck
To deck his ſtall? nay at the time of rapping,
When you may take the watch at corners napping;
Take it forſooth, it is a wondrous hap
If you finde Maſter Conſtable without his cap:
So a City Night-Cap; for whilſt he doth rome
And frights abroad, his wife commits at home.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: A Verona Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: A Conſtable of Verona; we will not meddle with your
City of Venice, ſir.
Therefore 'tis ſit the City, wiſe men ſay,
Should have a Cap call'd Cornucopia.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: To Con—

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: To conclude our Cap, and ſtretch it on the tenter,
'Tis known a City is the whole lands center:
So that a City-Night-Cap, ours we call
By a concluſion philoſophical.
Heavie bodies tend to th' center ſo (the more the pity)
The heavieſt heads do but upon the City:
And to our dance this title doth redound,
A City-Night-Cap, alias Cuckolds round.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Cuckolds round! and my ſweet bird leads the dance!

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Be patient, Madam, 'Tis but honeſt mirth:
From good conſtruction pleaſure findes full birth.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Jaspro, fill ſome wine.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: 'Tis here, ſir.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Count Lodovico!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: I'll inſtantly give you a fair occaſion to produce
The performance of her penance.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I'll catch occaſion by the lock, ſir.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Here, a health to all, it ſhall go round.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'Tis a general health, and leads the reſt into the field.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Your honour breaks jeſts as ſerving-men do glaſſes, by chance.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: As I was drinking, I was thinking, truſt me,
How fortunate our kind hoſt was to meet
With ſo chaſt a wife; troth tell me, good Count Lodowick,
Admit heaven had her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Oh good your Grace, do not wound me.
Admit heaven had her! alas what ſhould heaven do with her?

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Your love makes you thus paſſionate; but admit ſo:
Faith, what wife would you chuſe?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Were I to chuſe then, as I would I were, ſo this were at Japan,
I would wiſh, my Lord, a wife ſo like my Lady,
That once a week ſhe ſhould go to confeſſion;
And to perform the penance ſhe ſhould run,
Nay ſhould do nought, but dream on't till 'twere done.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: A delicate memento, to put her in mind of her penance.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Now you talk of dreams; ſweet heart, I'll tell ye a very unhappie one; I was a dream'd laſt night of Francis there.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Of Franck?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay, I have done with him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Now your Grace ſhall ſee the devil out-done.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Pray let us hear your dream?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Bleſs me! I am e'en aſham'd to tell it: but 'tis no matter, chick,
A dream is a dream, and this it was:
Me thought, ſweet husband, Francis lay with me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The beſt friend ſtill at home, Franciſco.
Could the devil, ſir, perform a penance neater,
And ſave his credit better? on, chick, a dream is but a dream.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Me thought I prov'd with child, ſweet heart.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I, bird?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Pox of theſe dreams.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Me thought I was brought to bed, and one day ſitting
I'th' gallery, where your Masking ſuits and vizards hang,
Having the child me thought upon my knee,
Who ſhould come thither as to play at ſoils,
But thou, ſweet heart, and Francis?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Frank and I! does your Grace mark that?

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: I do, and wonder at her neat conveyance on't.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Ye had not play'd three venies, but me thought
He hot thee ſuch a blow upon the forehead,
It ſwel'd ſo that thou couldſt not ſee:

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: See, ſee!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: At which the child cri'd, ſo that I could not ſtill it;
Whereat, me thought, I pray'd thee to put on
The hat thou wor'ſt but now before the Duke, thinking thereby
To ſtill the child: but being frighted with't,
He cri'd the more.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He? Frank thou get'ſt boys.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: In dreams it ſeems, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: VVhereat I cri'd, me thought, pointing to thee,
Away you naughty man, you are not this childs father.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Meaning the child Franciſco got.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The ſame: and then I wak'd and kiſt thee.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A pretty merry dream!

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Your ſervant tells me,
Count Lodowick, that one father Antony,
A holy man, ſtays without to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: VVith me, or my Lady?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Nay, with you, and about earneſt buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I'll go ſend him up, and he ſhall interpret my Ladies dream. Piſt Jaspro.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: VVhy husband, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Didſt mark? I muſt interpret.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: I ſmell worm-wood and vineger.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: She changes colour.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He will not ſure reveal confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: VVe'll riſe and to our lodging: I think your Highneſs
Keeps better hours in Venice?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: As all do, ſir,
VVe many times make modeſt mirth, a neceſſity
To produce Ladies dreams.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How they ſhoot at us! would I were in Millain:
Theſe paſſages frye me.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Here's ſtrange jugling come to light.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Ha, jugling!

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: This Fryer hath confeſt unto Count Lodowick.
That his Lady here being abſolv'd,
Confeſs'd this morning to him here, in her own houſe,
Her man Franciſco here had lain with her.
At which her Lord runs up and down the garden
Like one diſtracted, crying, Ware hornes ho.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Art mad? deny it yet, I am undone elſe.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Father Tony.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I confeſs it, I deny it, I any thing, I do every thing, I do nothing.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: The Fryer's fallen Frantick; and being mad,
Depraves a Lady of ſo chaſt a breſt
A bad thought never bred there.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Tis my misfortune ſtill to ſuffer, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Did you not ſee one ſlip out of a cloak-bag i'th' faſhion of a flitch of bacon, and run under the table amongſt the hogs?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: He's mad, he's mad.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I, I, a tythe-pig twas overlaid laſt night, and he ſpeaks nonſence all the day after.—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Shall I, ſir, ſuffer this in mine own houſe too?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: I'd ſcratch out's his eyes firſt.

sp.speaker: Vero
sp.l: Since Lady you and your man Franciſco
Are the two injur'd perſons, here diſrobe
This Irregular ſon of his religious mother,
Expoſe him to the apparent bluſh of ſhame,
And tear thoſe holy weeds off.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Now you my frantick brother,
Had you not been better ſpar'd your breath?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And ye keep counſel ſir no better?
We'll eaſe you of your orders.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Nay, let me have a hand in't: I'll tear his coat with more zeal then a Puritan would tear a ſurplis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: See what 'tis to accuſe when you're mad.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I confeſs again to you now ſir, this man did lie with me.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: And I brought him to her chamber too: but come, turn out here.

sp.speaker: Dukes.
sp.l: Who's this?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: 'Tis Count Lodowick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How dreams, ſweet wife, do fall out true!

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: I was a dream'd, now I remember, I was whipt through Verona.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I was your confeſſor:
Did not I enjoyn your chaſte nice Ladiſhip
A dainty penance?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: And ſhe perform'd it as daintily, ſir, we'll be ſworn for that.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Oh good ſir, I crave your pardon!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And what ſay you, Francis?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You have run beſt ſir, vain 'tis to defend,
Craft ſets forth ſwift, but ſtill fails in the end.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You brought him to her chamber, Pambo.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Good my Lord, I was merely inveagled to't.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I have nothing to do with ye, I take no notice of ye, I have plaid my part off to th' life, and your Grace promis'd to perform yours.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: And publickly we will ſtill raiſe their fame:
VVho ere knew private ſin ſcape publick ſhame?
You ſir that do appear a gentleman,
Yet are within ſlave to diſhoneſt paſſions;
You ſhall through Verona ride upon an Aſs
VVith your face towards his back-parts, and in your hand his tail 'ſtead of a bridle.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: 'Snailes, upon and Aſſe: an 'th nd been upon an horſe it had been worthy gramercy.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Peace, ſirrah:
After that, you ſhall be branded in the forehead,
And after baniſh'd: away with him!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Luſt is ſtill
Like a midnight-meal, after our violent drinkings,
'Tis ſwallowed greedily: but the courſe being kept,
We are ſicker when we wake then ere we ſlept.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: He muſt be branded, if the whore-maſter be burnt: what ſhall become of the procurer?

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: You Madam, in that you have coferr'd ſanctity,
To promiſe her the vows you never paid,
You ſhall unto the Monaſterie of Matrons,
And ſpend your daies recluſive: for we conceive it
Her greateſt plague, who her daies in luſt hath paſt
And ſoil'd, againſt her will to be kept chaſte.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Your doom is juſt, no ſentence can be given
Too hard for her plays faſt and looſe with heaven.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I will buſs thee, and bid fair weather after thee: but for you, ſirrah.—

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Nay ſir, 'tis but Crede quod habes & habes, at moſt; believe I have a halter, and I have one.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: You ſirrah, we are poſſeſt were their pander.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I brought but fleſh to fleſh ſir, and your Grace does as much when you bring your meat to your mouth.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: You ſirrah at a Carts tail ſhall be whipt Through the City.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: there's my dream out already; but ſince there is no remedy but that whipping-chear muſt cloſe up my ſtomach, I would requeſt a noat from your Grace, to the Carman, to intreat him to drive apace; I ſhall never indure it elſe.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: I hope, Count Lodowick, we have ſatisfied ye.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: To th' full; and I think the Cuckold catch'd the Cuckold-makers.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: 'Twas a neat penance; but oh! the art of woman in the performance.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Pſhew ſir, 'tis nothing, had ſhe been in her great Granams place.
Had not the Devil firſt began the ſin,
And cheated her, ſhe would have cheated him.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: Let all to reſt; and noble ſir, i'th' morning,
With a ſmall private train, we are for Millain.
Vice for a time may ſhine, and vertue ſigh;
But truth like heavens Sun plainly doth reveal,
And ſcourge or crown, what darkneſs did conceal.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter Antonio and a Slave, one in the others habit.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.l: BUt faith, ſir, what's your device in this? this change
Infinuates ſome project.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Shall I tell thee?
Thou art my Slave, I took thee (then a Turk,
In the fight thou knoweſt we made before Palermo)
Thou art not in ſtricter bondage unto me
Then I am unto Cupid.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.l: Oh then you are going, ſir,
To your old rendevow, there are brave rogues there:
But the Duke obſerves you narrowly, and ſets ſpies
To watch if you ſtep that way.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Why therefore man,
Thus many times, I have chang'd habits with thee,
To cheat ſuſpition, and prejudicate nature
(Miſtres of inclinations) ſure intended,
To knit thee up ſo like me, for this purpoſe,
For th'aſt been taken in my habit for me.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.l: Yes, and have had many a French cringe
As I have walk'd i'th' Park; and for fear of diſcovery,
I have crown'd it only with a nod.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Th'art a mad villain:
But ſirrah, I am wondrouſly taken
With a ſweet face I ſaw yonder; thou knowſt where.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.l: At Venus Colledge, the Court-baudy-houſe.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: But this, man, howſoever ſhe came there,
Is acquainted ſo with heaven, that when I thought
To have quench'd my frantick blood, and to have pluck'd
The fruit a king would leap at; even then ſhe beat me
With ſuch brave thunder off, as if heaven had lent her
The Artillery of Angels.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.l: She was coy then.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Coy, man! ſhe was honeſt; left coyneſs to court-Ladies:
She ſpake the language of the ſaints, me thought.
Holy ſpectators ſate on ſilver Clouds,
And clapt their white wings at her well-plac'd words.
She peicemeal pull'd the frame of my intentions,
And ſo joyn'd it again, that all the tempeſt
Of blood can never move it.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.l: Some rare Phaenix, what's her name?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: 'Tis Millecenta, and wondrous aptly,
For ſhe is Miſtreſs of a hundred thouſand holy heavenly thoughts.
Chaſtly I love her now, and ſhe muſt know it:
Such wondrous wealth is vertue, it makes the woman
Wears it about her worthy of a king;
Since kings can be but vertuous, farewel.
A crown is but the care of deceiv'd life,
He's king of men, is crown'd with ſuch a wife.
sp.stage: Exit Antonio, and the Lord after him.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.l: Are your thoughts levell'd at that white then?
This ſhall to th' Duke your dad, ſir; he can never talk with me,
But he twits me ſtill with, I took thee at that fight
VVe made before Parlermo; I did command
Men as he did there, Turks and valaint men:
And though to wind my ſelf up for his ruine,
That I may fall and cruſh him, I appear
'To renounce Mahomet, and ſeem a Chriſtian;
Tis but conveniently to ſtab this Chriſtian,
Or any way confound him, and ſcape cleanly,
And one expects the deed: to haſten it,
This letter came even now, which likewiſe certifies
He waits me three leagues off, with a horſe for flight
Of a Turkiſh Captain commander of a Gally:
He keeps me as his ſlave, becauſe indeed
I plaid the devil at ſea, with him; but having
Thus wrought my ſelf into him, I intend
To give him but this day to take his leave
Of the whole world; he will come back by twilight:
I'll wait him with a piſtol: Oh ſweet revenge!
Laugh our great prophet, he ſhall underſtand,
When we think death fartheſt off, he's neereſt hand.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You and I muſt meet no more ſir; there's your kick again.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.l: Hold, hold, what mean you ſir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I have brought your kick back ſir—

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.l: Hold man, I am not—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou haſt ſpoken true, thou art not—What art thou?
But I am for Verona.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.l: Mine own words catch me, 'tis I now underſtand,
When we think death fartheſt off, he's neereſt hand.
She lives not ſure in Millain: report but wore
Her uſual habit, when ſhe told in Verona,
She met Abſtemia here: Oh Abſtemia!
How lovely thou look'ſt now? now thou appeareſt
Chaſter then is the mornings modeſtie
That riſes with a bluſh, over whoſe boſom
The Weſtern wind creeps ſoftly: Now I remember
How when ſhe ſat at Table, her obedient eye
Would dwell on mine, as if it were not well,
Unleſs it look'd where I look'd: Oh how proud
She was, when ſhe could croſs her ſelf to pleaſe me!
But where now is this fair ſoul? like a ſilver cloud
She hath wept her ſelf, I fear, into th' dead ſea,
And will be found no more: this makes me mad,
To rave and call on death; but the ſlave ſhrinks,
And is as far to finde, as ſhe. Abſtemia,
If thou not anſwer or appear to knowledg,
That here with ſhame I ſought thee in this wood,
I'll leave the bluſhing witneſs of my blood.
sp.stage: Enter the Duke of Millain, Sebeſtian, Sanchio, and the Lord.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Followed you him thus far?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Juſt to this place, fir:
The ſlave he loves left him, here they parted.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Certain he has ſome private haunt this way.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ha—private indeed, ſir: Oh behold and ſee
Where he lies full of wounds!

sp.speaker: Lords.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: My ſon Antonio! who hath done this deed?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: My Lord Antonio!

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: He's gone, he's gone; warm yet, bleeds freſh, and whilſt
We here hold paſſion play, we but advantage
The flying murderer. Bear his body gently
Unto the lodge: Oh what hand hath ſo hid
That ſunlike face, behind a crimſon cloud!
Uſe all means poſſible for life: but I fear
Charity will arrive too late. To horſe,
Diſperſe through the wood, run, ride, make way,
The Sun in Millain is eclips'd this day.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: To horſe, and raiſe more purſuit.
sp.stage: Enter Lorenzo, with his ſword drawn.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Abſtemia! Oh take her name you winds upon your wings,
And through the wanton Region of the Air,
Softly convey it to her: there's no ſweet ſufferance,
Which bravely ſhe paſt through, but is a thorn
Now to my ſides: my will the center ſtood
To all her chaſte endeavours: all her actions,
With a perfection perpendicular,
Pointed upon, ſhe is loſt; Oh ſhe
The well-built fort of vertues victory!
For ſtill ſhe conquer'd: ſince ſhe is loſt, then,
My friendly ſword find thou my heart.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: This way, what's he? lay hands on him.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: The murderer on my life, my Lord, here in the wood
Was cloſe beſet, he would have ſlain himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Speak villain, art thou the bloody murderer?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Of whom?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: His diſſembled ignorance ſpeaks him the man.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Of the Dukes ſon, the Prince Antonio, ſir; 'twas your hand that kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip lyes, it was my ſword.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Out ſlave!
Ravens ſhall fedſt upon thee: Speak, what cauſe
Hadſt thou with one unhappy wound, to cloud
That Star of Millain?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Becauſe he was an erring ſtar,
Not fix'd nor regular; I will reſolve nothing:
I did it, do not repent it; and were it
To do again, I'd do't.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Blood-thirſty villain!

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Leave him to ſwift deſtruction, tortures and death.
Oh my Antonio! how did thy youth ſtray,
To meet wild winter, in the midſt of May?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Oh my Abſtemia! Who caſt thy fate ſo bad,
To clip affliction, like a husband clad?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Good ſir, the Prince makes known his wiſdom,
To make you ſpeaker in his cauſe.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Me? know, Miſtreſs,
I have felt loves paſſions equal with himſelf,
And can diſcourſe of loves cauſe: had you ſeen him
When he ſent me to ye, how truly he did look;
And when your name ſlip'd through his trembling lips,
A lovers lovely paleneſs ſtraight poſſeſt him.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Go ſays he to that ſomething more then woman,
(And he look'd as if by ſomething he meant ſaint)
Tell her I ſaw heavens army in her eyes,
And that from her chaſte heart, ſuch excellent goodneſs
Came like full rivers flowing; that there wants nothing
But her ſoft yeilding will, to make her wife
Unto the Prince Antonio: Oh will you flie
A fortune which great Ladies would purſue
Upon their knees with prayers?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: No, Lorenzo:
Had law to this new love made no denial,
A chaſte wifes truth ſhines through the greateſt tryal.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: How now, what makes you i'th' wood here? where's my old Lady?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: All the countrie's in an uprore yonder, the Prince Antonio's flain.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nay no man can tell how; but the murderer with's ſword in's hand is taken.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Is he of Millain?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No, of Verona: I heard his name, and I have forgot it.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: I am all wonder, 'tis the ſlave ſure.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Ha, Lorenzo! VVhat I pray?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Lorenzo Me—Medico has run him in the eye, ſome thirty three inches, two barly corns: they could ſcarce know him for the blood, but by his apparel. I muſt find out my Lady: he us'd our houſe, intelligence has been given of his pilgrimage thither: I am affraid I ſhall be fing'd to death with torches, and my Lady ſtew'd between two diſnes.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: VVhy hath this thus amaz'd you, Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Oh leave me, leave me, I am all diſtraction, Struck to the ſoul with ſorrow.
sp.stage: Enter Millain, Lords and Lorenzo guarded.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: See where they come:
My father full of tears too? I'll ſtand by:
Strange changes muſt have ſtrange diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: 'Tis he: heart, how thou leap'ſt! Oh ye deluded,
And full of falſe raſh judgement! why do ye lead
Innocence like a ſacrifice to ſlaughter?
Get garlands rather, let palm and lawrel round
Thoſe temples, where ſuch wedlock-truth is found.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Oh Lorenzo! thou haſt ſuffer'd bravely,
And wondrous far: look on me, here I come
Hurried by conſcience to confeſs the deed:
Thy innocent blood will be too great a burthen
Upon the judges ſoul.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Look, look how he will blind ye; by and by he'll tell ye
We ſaw not one another many a day,
In loves cauſe we dare make our lives away.
He would redeem mine, 'tis my husband, ſir,
Dearly we love together: but I being often
By the dead Prince your ſon ſolicited
To wrong my husband bed, and ſtill reſiſting,
Where you found him dead, he met me, and the place
Preſenting oportunity, he would there
Have forc'd me to his will; but prizing honeſty
Far above proffer'd honour, with my knife
In my reſiſtance moſt unfortunately
I ſtruck him in the eye: he fell, was found,
The purſuit rais'd, and ere I could get home
My husband met me, I confeſt all to him:
He excellent in love as the ſea-inhabitant,
Of whom 'tis writ, that when the flattering hook
Has ſtruck his female, he will help her off
Although he deſperately put on himſelf;
But if he fail, and ſee her leave his eye,
He ſwims to land, will languiſh and there die:
Such is his love to me; for purſu'd cloſely,
He bid me ſave my ſelf, and he would ſtay
With his drawn ſword, there about the place, on purpoſe
To require my loyalty, though with his death.
Fear forc'd my acceptance then, but conſcience
Hath brought me back to preſerve innocence.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The circumſtances produce probability.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: By truth her ſelf, ſhe ſlanders truth: ſhe and I
Have not met theſe many months: Oh my Abſtemia!
Thou wouldſt be now too excellent.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Theſe are ſtrange turns.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Let not love ſtrangle juſtice; ſpeak on thy ſoul,
Was it her hand, that ſlew the Prince?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Not, on my life,
'Tis I have deſerv'd death.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Love makes him deſperate,
Conſcience is my accuſer: Oh Lorenzo!
Live thou and feed on my remembrance,
When thou ſhalt think how ardently I lov'd thee;
Drop but a pair of tears, from thoſe fair eyes,
Thou offer'ſt truth a wealthy ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Did ye hear her, ſir?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: No, what ſaid ſhe?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: She ask'd me why I would caſt my ſelf away thus,
VVhen ſhe in love devis'd this trick to ſave me?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: There may be jugling ſir in this, it may be
They have both hands i'th' deed, and one in love
VVould ſuffer for't.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: VVhat newes?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The Dukes of Venice and Verona
VVith ſome ſmall train of gentlemen are privately
This hour come to th' Court.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Bear them to priſon,
Until we have given ſuch entertainment, ſorrow
VVill give us leave to ſhew: until that time
The ſatisfaction of my loſt ſons life
Muſt hover 'twixt a husband and a wife.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: How ſtrangely chance to day runs! the ſlave kill'd
In my apparel, and this fellow taken for't,
VVhom to my knowledg I ne'er ſaw: ſhe loves him
Paſt all expreſſion dearly: I have a trick
In that ſo infinitely dear ſhe loves him,
Has ſeal'd her mine already; and I'll put
This wondrous love of woman to ſuch a nonplus,
Time hath produc'd none ſtranger: I will ſet
Honour and love to fight ſo life and death:
Beautie (as Caſtles built of cards) with a breath
Is levell'd and laid flat.
sp.stage: Enter Philippo, putting on a diſguiſe, lays down a piſtol.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Miſery of ignorance!
It was the Prince Antonio I have ſlain.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Ha! the clew of all this errour is unravelled;
This is the valiant gentleman ſo threaten'd me;
He met the flave doubtleſs in my habit,
And ſeal'd upon him his miſtaken ſpleen:
If it be ſo, there hangs ſome ſtrange intent
In thoſe accuſe themſelves for't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It ſeems ſome other had laid the plot to kill him;
This paper I found with him, ſpeaks as much,
And ſent to the intended murderer,
Happen'd it ſeems to his hands: it concurs;
For, they ſay, there is one taken for the fact,
And will do me the courteſie to be hang'd for me:
There's comfort yet in that: ſo, ſo, I am fitted,
And will ſet forward.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Gooſe, there's a fox in your way.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Betray'd!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Come, I have other buſineſs afoot; I have no time to diſcover 'em now, ſir; ſee, I can inforce ye: but by this hand, go but with me, and keep your own counſel; garden-houſes are not truer bawds to cuckold-making, then I will be to thee, and thy ſtratagem.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Th'art a mad knave, art ſerious?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: As a uſurer when he's telling intereſt-mony.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: VVhatere thou art, thy bluntneſs begets belief: go on,
I truſt thee.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: But I have more wit then to truſt you behind me ſir: pray get you before, I have a private friend ſhall keep you in cuſtody, till I have paſt a project; and if you can keep your own counſel, I will not injure you: and this for your comfort, the Prince lives.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Living! thou mak'ſt my blood dance: but prithee let's be honeſt one to another.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p:
Oh ſir, as the Juſtices clarke, and the Conſtable, when
they ſhare the crowns that drunkards pay to the poor; pray keep fair diſtance, and take no great ſtrides.
sp.stage: Enter Lorenzo and Abſtemia, as in priſon.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Can then Abſtemia forgive Lotenzo?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Yes, if Lorenzo can but love Abſtemia,
She can thus hang upon his neck, and call
This priſon true loves palace.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Oh let Kings
Forget their crowns, that know what 'tis to enjoy
The wondrous wealth of one ſo good; now
Thou art lovely as a young ſpring, and cornly
As is the well-ſpread Cedar; the fair fruit,
Kiſt by the ſun ſo daily, that it wears
The lovely bluſh of maids, ſeems but to mock
Thy ſouls integrity; here let me fall,
And with pleading ſighs beg pardon.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Sir, it meets you,
Like a glad pilgrim, whoſe deſiring eye,
Longs for the long-wiſh'd altar of his vow;
But you are far too prodigall in praiſe,
And crown me with the garlands of your merit,
As we meet barks on rivers, the ſtrong gale,
(Being beſt friends to us) our own ſwift motion
Makes us believe that t'other mimbler rows,
Swift vertue thinks ſmall goodneſs faſteſt goes.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Sorrow hath bravely ſweetned thee: what are you?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: A diſpleaſant black cloud: though I appear diſmal,
I am wondrous fruitful: what cauſe ſoever
Mov'd you to take this murder on yourſelf,
Or you to ſtrike your ſelf into the hazard
I or his redemption, 'tis to me a ſtranger,
But I conceive you are both innocent.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: As new-born vertue, I did accuſe
My innocence to rid me of a life
Lookt uglier then death, upon an injury
I had done this vertuous wife.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: And I accusd
My innocence to ſave the belov'd life
Of my moſt noble husband.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Why then? now 'twould grieve you,
Death ſhould unkindly part ye.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Oh but that, ſir,
We have no ſorrow: now to part from her,
(Since heaven hath new married, and new made us)
I had rather leap into a den of Lyons,
Snatch from a hungry Bear her bleeding prey,
I would attempt deſperate impoſſibilities
With hope, rather then now to leave her.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: This makes for me.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: And rather then leave you, ſir, I would eat
Hot coles with Portia, or attempt a terrour,
Nature would ſnail-like ſhrink her head in at,
And tremble but to think on.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Better and better!
If you ſo love him, what can you confeſs?
The greateſt kindneſs can expreſs that love.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: To ſave his life, ſince there is no hope,
Seeing he ſo ſtrongly has confeſt the murder,
We ſhall meet the happyneſs to dye together.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Fire caſts the braveſt heat in coldeſt weather,
I'll try how ardently you burn; for know
Upon my faith, and as I am a gentleman,
I have (in the next room, and in the cuſtody
Of a true friend) the man that did the deed
You ſtand accus'd for.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Hark there, Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Will you not let him go, ſir?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: That's in ſuſpence; but miſtreſs, you did ſay
You durſt eat coals with Protia, to redeem
The infinitely loved life of your husband.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: And ſtill ſtrongly proteſt it.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Oh my Abſtemia!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: You ſhall redeem him at an eaſier rate:
I have the murderer you ſee in hold.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And we are bleſt in your diſcovery of him.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: If you will give conſent that I ſhall taſte
That ſence-bereaving pleaſure ſo familiar
Unto your happy husband.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Pray hear me:
Then I will give this fellow up to th' law:
If you deny, horſes ſtand ready for us,
A bark for tranſportation, where we will live
Till law by death hath ſever'd ye.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But we will call for preſent witneſs.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Look ye—
Experienc'd navigators ſtill are fitted,
For every weather: 'tis almoſt paſt call
To reach the nimbleſt ear: yet but offer it,
I part ye preſently for ever.
Conſider it;
The enjoying him thou ſo intirely lov'ſt
All thy life after; that when mirth-ſpent time
Hath crown'd your heads with honour, you may ſit
And tell delightful ſtories of your loves:
And when ye come to that poor minutes ſcape
Crowns my deſire, ye may let that ſlip by,
Like water that ne'er the meets Millers eye:
Compare but this, to th' ſoon-forgotten pleaſure
Of a pair of wealthy minutes: the thirſtieſt Lapidarie
Knows the moſt curious Jewel takes no harm,
For one days wearing: could you ſir (did your eye
Not ſee it worne) your wife having lent your cloak,
(If ſecretly return'd and folded up)
Could you conceive, when you next look'd upon't,
It had neatly furniſh'd our a poor friends want?
Be charitable, and think on't.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Doſt hear, Abſtemia?
Oh ſhall we part for ever, when a price
So poor might be our freedome?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Now goodneſs guard ye!
Where learnt you, ſir, this language?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Of true love:
You did but now profeſs, that you would dye
To ſave my life, and now like a forward chapman,
Catch'd at thy word, thou giv'ſt back aſham'd
To ſtand this eaſie proffer.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Could you live,
And know your ſelfe a cuckold?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: What a queſtion's that?
Many men cannot live without the knowledge:
How can ye tell,
Whether ſhe ſeems thus to reſpect your honour,
But to ſtay till the law has choak'd ye? it may be then
She will do't, with leſs intreaty.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I, there, there 'tis.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: 'Tis your old fit of jealouſie, ſo judges:
A foul devil talks within him.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Oh the art,
The wondrous art of woman! ye would do it daintily,
You would juggle me to death, you would perſwade me
I ſhould dye nobly to preſerve your honour;
That dead ignobly you might prove diſhonourable,
Forget me in a day, and wed another.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Why then would I have dyed for you?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: That was but a proffer, that dying you might Idolize her love;
'Twould have put her off the better.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Oh you have builded
A golden Palace, ſtrew'd with Palm and Roſes,
To let me bleed to death in! How ſweetly
You would have loſt me! Abſtemia, you have learn'd,
The cunning Fowlers art, who pleaſantly
Whiſtles the bird into the ſnare: good heaven!
How you had ſtrew'd the inticing top o'th' cup
With Arabian Spices! but you had laid i'th' bottom
Epheſian Aconite: you are loves hypocrite:
A rotten ſtick in the nights darkneſs born,
And a fair Poppie in a field of corn.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Oh ſir I hear me—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Away, I will no more
Look pearl in mud: Oh ſlie hypocriſie!
Durſt ye but now die for me? good heaven! die for me!
The greateſt act of pain, and dare not buy me
With a poor minutes pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: No ſir, I dare not; there is little pain in death,
But a great death in very little pleaſure:
I had rather, truſt me, bear your death with honour,
Then buy your life with baſeneſs: as I am expos'd
To th' greateſt battery beauty ever fought,
Oh blame me not, if I be covetous
To come off with greateſt honour; if I do this
To let you live, I kill your name, and give
My ſoul a wound; I cruſh her from ſweet grace,
And change her Angels to a furies face:
Try me no more then, but if you muſt bleed, boaſt,
To preſerve honour, life is nobly loſt.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Thou wealth worth more then kingdoms, I am now confirm'd,
Paſt all ſuſpition, thou that art far ſweeter
In thy ſincere truth, then a ſacrifice
Deck'd up for death with garlands: the Indian winds
That blow off from the coaſt, and cheer the Saylor
With the ſweet ſavour of their ſpices, want
The delight flowes in thee: look here, look here,
Oh man of wilde deſires; we will die the Martyrs
Of Marriage, and ſtead of the looſe ditties
With which; they ſtab ſweet modeſtie, and ingender
Deſires in the hot room; thy noble ſtorie
Shall lawrel-like crown honeſt ears with glory.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Murder, murder, murder!
sp.stage: Enter the three Dukes, with Lords.

sp.speaker: Mill
sp.l: Ha, who cries murder?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: As y'are a gentleman, now be true to me.

sp.speaker: Abſt
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Siſter?

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: My ſhame, art thou there?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Oh ſiſter, can it be
A Princes blood ſhould ſtain that white hand?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: Hear us.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: No, no, no, hear me, 'twas I cry'd murder:
Becauſe I have found them both ſtain'd with the deed,
They would have throtled me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Hear us, by all.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Upon your lives be ſilent; ſpeak on, ſir:
Had they both hands in our ſons blood?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Two hands apiece, ſir:
I have fifted it, they both have kill'd the Prince;
But this is the chief murderer: pleaſe you give me audience,
Ye ſhall wonder at the manner how they kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: He came firſt to this woman, and truth's truth,
He would have lain with her.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Her own confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Nay good your Grace.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: We are ſilent.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Coming to ſeiſe upon her, with the firſt blow
She ſtruck his baſe intent ſo brave a buffer,
That there it bled to death: ſhe ſaid his horſe
Would teach him better manners: there he dy'd once.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: VVhat does this fellow talk?

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: I underſtand him.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: He met her next i'th' wood, where he was found dead:
Then he came noblier up to her, and told her
Marriage was his intent; but ſhe as nobly,
(Belike to let him know ſhe was married)
Told him in an intelligible denial,
A chaſte wives truth ſhin'd through the greateſt tryal:
There the Prince dy'd again.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: There's twice, beware the third time.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: The third time, he came here to them both in priſon,
Brought a piſtol with him, would have forc'd her again,
But had ye ſeen how fairly then ſhe flew him,
You would have ſhot applauſes from your eyes:
Oh ſhe came up ſo bravely to that Prince,
Hot potent Luſt, (for ſhe ſlew no Prince elſe)
With ſuch a valiant diſcipline ſhe deſtroy'd
That deboſh'd Prince, Bad Deſire; and then by him
So bravely too fetch'd off, that (to conclude)
Betwixt them they this wonder did contrive,
They kill'd the Prince, but kept your ſon alive

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: The Prince.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Come home my ſiſter to my heart.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: And now Lorenzo is again my belov'd kinfman,

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Oh ſir, here dwells vertue epitomiz'd,
Even to an abſtract, and yet that ſo large,
'Twill ſwell a book in folio.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: She ſwells beyond my wife then:
A pocket-book bound in Decimo Sexto
Will hold her vertues, and as much ſpare paper left
As will furniſh five Tobacco-ſhops

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: But here's the wonder, who is it was ſlain
In your apparel?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I will give them all the ſlip.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Here's a gentleman of Ferrara.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: As you are noble.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: That ſaw them fight: it was the Slave was ſlain, ſir,
I took before Palermo; he that kill'd him,
Took him but for a gentleman his equal:
And as this eye-witnſs ſays, he in my apparel
Did kick the t'other firſt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay, upon my life, ſir.
He in your apparel gave the firſt kick; I ſaw them fight,
And I dare ſwear the t'other honeſt gentleman
Little thought he had ſlain any thing like the Prince;
For I heard him ſwear but half an hour before,
He never ſaw your Grace.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Then he kill'd him fairly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Upon my life, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: T'other had but his merit then: who dies,
And ſeeks his death, ſeldom wets others eyes.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Let this perſwade you, I believe you noble,
I have kept my word with you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You have out-done me, ſir,
In this brave exerciſe of honour: but let me
In mine own perſon thank you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Unwittingly I did an ill (as 't happen'd)
To a good end: that ſlave I for you kill'd,
Wanted but time to kill you: Read that paper
Which I found with him, I thinking by accident
You had intercepted it: we all have happily
Been well deceiv'd; you are noble, juſt and true;
My hate was at your cloathes, my heart at you.

sp.speaker: Vero.
sp.l: An accident more ſtrange hath ſeldome happen'd.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Philippo, my beſt friend, 'twixt ſhame and love
Here let me lay thee now for ever.

sp.speaker: Abſt.
sp.l: Heaven
Hath now plain'd all our rough woes ſmooth and even.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: At Court, large relation in apt form
Shall tender paſt proceedings; but to diſtinguſh
(Excellent Lady) your unparallel'd praiſes
From thoſe but ſeem, let this ſerve: bad women,
Are natures clouds eclipſing her fair ſhine;
The good, all gracious, ſaint-like and divine.
